content: NCCN Guidelines focus on Head and Neck Cancers.
The NCCN Guidelines discuss the multidisciplinary team and support services (TEAM-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss cancer of the oral cavity (including mucosal lip) (OR-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss cancer of the oropharynx (ORPH-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss p16-negative cancer of the oropharynx (ORPH-2).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss p16 (HPV)-positive cancer of the oropharynx (ORPHPV-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss cancer of the hypopharynx (HYPO-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss cancer of the nasopharynx (NASO-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss systemic therapy for nasopharyngeal cancers (NASO-B).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss cancer of the glottic larynx (GLOT-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss cancer of the supraglottic larynx (SUPRA-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss ethmoid sinus tumors (ETHM-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss maxillary sinus tumors (MAXI-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss very advanced head and neck cancer (ADV-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss recurrent/persistent very advanced head and neck cancer (ADV-3).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss occult primary (OCC-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss salivary gland tumors (SALI-1).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss systemic therapy for salivary gland tumors (SALI-B).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss mucosal melanoma (MM-1).
The NCCN Guidelines provide follow-up recommendations (FOLL-A).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss principles of imaging (IMG-A).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss principles of surgery (SURG-A).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss principles of radiation techniques (RAD-A).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss principles of systemic therapy for non-nasopharyngeal cancers (SYST-A).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss principles of nutrition: management and supportive care (NUTR-A).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss principles of oral/dental evaluation and management (DENT-A).
The NCCN Guidelines discuss staging (ST-1).
NCCN Guidelines Version 2.2024 is a version of the NCCN Guidelines for Head and Neck Cancers.
OR-3 includes clinical staging and selected patients who decline or are unfit for surgery.
A pathway for concurrent systemic therapy/RT or definitive RT was removed in OR-3.
A pathway for post systemic therapy/RT or RT neck evaluation was removed in OR-3.
A pathway for recurrent or persistent disease was removed in OR-3.
A follow-up for very advanced head and neck cancer was added in OR-3.
NASO-B includes recurrent, unresectable, oligometastatic, or metastatic disease with no surgery or RT option.
A preferred first-line regimen was added in NASO-B.
A preferred subsequent-line regimen was added in NASO-B.
HYPO-2 includes a modified treatment of primary and neck option.
HYPO-3 includes a modified treatment of primary and neck option.
HYPO-5 includes a modified treatment of primary and neck option.
NASO-A includes a note about hyperfractionation for locally advanced nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
NASO-B includes a recurrent, unresectable, oligometastatic, or metastatic disease option.
SUPRA-2 includes a modified treatment of primary and neck option.
ETHM-1 includes a new footnote.
ETHM-2 includes a primary treatment option.
ADV-1 was updated to include concurrent systemic therapy/RT as a preferred option for treatment of primary and neck.
PS2 was modified to include concurrent systemic therapy/RT as a preferred option.
SALI-2 was updated to include complete resection as an option for adenoid cystic intermediate or higher grade, with a category of evidence modified for RT for T1 disease from 2B to 2A.
SALI-3 was updated to include complete resection as an option for adenoid cystic, with a category of evidence modified for RT from 2B to 2A.
SALI-B was updated to include androgen receptor (AR) therapy for AR+ tumors as useful in certain circumstances.
Abiraterone was added as a regimen for AR+ tumors.
Goserelin was added as a regimen for AR+ tumors with a category of evidence of 2B.
Axitinib + avelumab was added as a regimen for ACC with a category of evidence of 2B.
Fam-trastuzumab deruxtecan-nxki was modified to have a category of evidence of 2A.
FOLL-A was updated to include annual evaluation of panhypopituitarism following RT to the skull base.
IMG-A was updated to include CT with contrast as an imaging option.
CT imaging of the chest can be performed with or without contrast, as clinically indicated.
MRI is performed with and without contrast, unless contraindicated.
CT is complementary to MRI for head and neck cancers for certain conditions.
CT is used to evaluate cortical bone erosion or periosteal invasion in oral cavity cancer.
CT is used to evaluate cartilage invasion in laryngeal cancer.
CT is used to evaluate bony erosion/destruction in sinonasal and skull base lesions.
MRI is used to evaluate the extent of bone marrow invasion or in patients with extensive dental amalgam that may obscure the anatomy on CT in oral cavity cancer.
MRI is used to assess skull base invasion and cranial nerve involvement in nasopharyngeal cancer.
MRI is used to evaluate skull base or intracranial or orbital invasion, and to differentiate tumor from obstructed sinuses in sinonasal cancer.
Sub-bullet 4 was modified to include any head and neck cancer with cranial nerve symptoms or radiographic perineural tumor spread as a possibility.
Bullet 5 was modified to state that US of the neck is a well-established tool useful for nodal surveillance.
US is generally widely available, safe, fast, inexpensive, and an accurate modality for examination of the neck for any suspicious nodal disease.
A clear margin is no longer defined as the distance from the invasive tumor front that is 5 mm or more from the resected margin.
A close margin is no longer defined as the distance from the invasive tumor front to the resected margin that is less than 2–5 mm, depending on the anatomic site involved.
There is no universal definition for what constitutes a clear/close margin.
Distance in mm to achieve clinically acceptable margins is influenced by tumor primary site, histology, and HPV status in oropharyngeal cancer and following neoadjuvant therapy.
Hyperfractionation for locally advanced nasopharyngeal carcinoma involves IMRT total dose of 65 Gy, in 54 fractions, twice daily, with an irradiation interval of 6–8 hours.
The choice of systemic therapy should be individualized based on patient characteristics (eg, PS, goals of therapy).
Next-generation sequencing (NGS) genomic profiling, including testing for CPS, may be considered to guide patient treatment options, including clinical trials.
Docetaxel (if cisplatin ineligible) is a useful regimen in certain circumstances for Primary Systemic Therapy + Concurrent RT.
Carboplatin/paclitaxel/cetuximab (category 2B) is a useful regimen in certain circumstances for Induction/Sequential Systemic Therapy.
Docetaxel/cisplatin/fluorouracil (category 2B) was added as a regimen for Induction/Sequential Systemic Therapy.
Docetaxel (if cisplatin ineligible) is a useful regimen in certain circumstances for Postoperative Systemic Therapy/RT.
Pembrolizumab/platinum (cisplatin or carboplatin)/paclitaxel (category 2B) is a modified regimen for Other recommended regimens.
Cetuximab/pembrolizumab (category 2B) is a modified regimen for Squamous cell carcinoma.
Paclitaxel/cetuximab is a added regimen for Squamous cell carcinoma.
Nivolumab/ipilimumab (CPS ≥20 and first-line only) (category 2B) is a added regimen for Squamous cell carcinoma.
Docetaxel/cetuximab (category 2B) is a added regimen for Squamous cell carcinoma.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancers is complex.

All patients with head and neck cancers need access to the full range of support services and specialists with expertise in the comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer for optimal treatment and follow-up.
Outcomes are improved when patients with head and neck cancers are treated in high-volume centers.
Follow-up should be performed by a physician and other health care professionals with expertise in the comprehensive care and prevention of treatment sequelae.
Follow-up should include a comprehensive head and neck exam.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve head and neck surgery.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve radiation oncology.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve medical oncology.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve plastic and reconstructive surgery.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve specialized nursing care.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve dentistry/prosthodontics.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve physical medicine and rehabilitation.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve speech and swallowing therapy.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve speech and swallowing therapy.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve clinical social work.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve clinical nutrition.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve pathology (including cytopathology).
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve diagnostic and interventional radiology.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve adjunctive services.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve neurosurgery.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve ophthalmology.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve psychiatry.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve addiction services.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve audiology.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve audiology.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve palliative care.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve pain management.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve general medical care.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve pain and symptom management.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve nutritional support.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve enteral feeding.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve oral nutrition.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve dental care for RT effects.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve xerostomia management.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve smoking and alcohol cessation.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve tracheotomy care.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve wound management.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve depression assessment and management.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve social work and case management.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve care coordination.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve supportive care.
The comprehensive care of patients with head and neck cancer may involve physical therapy (lymphedema management).
H&P should include documentation and quantification of tobacco use history.
H&P should include documentation and quantification of alcohol use and counseling.
All patients who currently smoke should be advised to quit smoking.
Those who formerly smoked should be advised to remain abstinent from smoking.
Additional cessation support can be found in the NCCN Guidelines for Smoking Cessation.
Patients should be screened for depression according to the NCCN Guidelines for Distress Management.
The oral cavity includes buccal mucosa, floor of mouth, oral tongue, alveolar ridge, retromolar trigone, and hard palate.
The workup includes history and physical including a complete head and neck exam.
The workup includes mirror and fiberoptic examination as clinically indicated.
The workup includes biopsy.
The workup includes chest CT with or without contrast as clinically indicated.
The workup includes CT with contrast and/or MRI with and without contrast of primary and neck as clinically indicated.
The workup includes consideration of FDG-PET/CT as clinically indicated.
The workup includes examination under anesthesia with endoscopy as clinically indicated.
The workup includes preanesthesia studies as clinically indicated.
The workup includes dental/prosthodontic evaluation including Panorex or dental CT without contrast as clinically indicated.
The workup includes nutrition, speech and swallowing evaluation/therapy as clinically indicated.
The workup includes smoking cessation counseling.
The workup includes fertility/reproductive counseling as clinically indicated.
The workup includes screening for hepatitis B as clinically indicated.
The workup includes multidisciplinary consultation as clinically indicated.
Image-guided needle biopsy of cystic neck nodes may offer better diagnostic yield than fine-needle aspiration by palpation alone for initial diagnosis.
A core biopsy would allow for ancillary immune-genomic testing for unresectable or metastatic disease where there is a plan for systemic therapy.
Buccal mucosa, floor of mouth, oral tongue, alveolar ridge, retromolar trigone, and hard palate are types of oral cavity cancers.
Clinical staging, treatment of primary and neck, adjuvant treatment, and follow-up are parts of the NCCN Guidelines for Cancer of the Oral Cavity.
T1–2, N0 is a clinical stage of cancer.
Resection of primary and + sentinel lymph node biopsy are treatment options for T1–2, N0 cancer.
Surgery is a preferred treatment option for T1–2, N0 cancer.
Definitive RT is a treatment option for SLN pN0 cancer.
Neck dissection is a treatment option if SLN pN+ or SLN identification is unsuccessful.
No positive nodes and no adverse pathologic features are characteristics of a type of cancer.
One positive node without adverse pathologic features is a characteristic of a type of cancer.

Adverse pathologic features include extranodal extension, positive margins, close margins, pT3 or pT4 primary, pN2 or pN3 nodal disease, nodal disease in levels IV or V, perineural invasion, vascular invasion, and lymphatic invasion.

Adverse pathologic features include extranodal extension, positive margins, close margins, pT3 or pT4 primary, pN2 or pN3 nodal disease, nodal disease in levels IV or V, perineural invasion, vascular invasion, and lymphatic invasion.
Positive margin is an adverse pathologic feature.
Extranodal extension ± positive margin is an adverse pathologic feature.
Consider RT is a treatment option for certain types of cancer.
Systemic therapy/RT is a treatment option for certain types of cancer.
Re-resection if feasible and consider radiation therapy if negative margins is a treatment option.
Consider systemic therapy/RT is a treatment option.
Recurrent or persistent disease is a type of cancer.
Neck dissection is generally not indicated for T1–3,N0 mucosal lip.
The affected areas in the oral cavity include buccal mucosa, floor of mouth, oral tongue, alveolar ridge, retromolar trigone, and hard palate.
Clinical staging, treatment of primary and neck, adjuvant treatment, and follow-up are important considerations for cancer of the oral cavity.
T3,N0; T1–3,N1–3; T4a,N0–3 are classifications for cancer of the oral cavity.
Surgery is the preferred treatment for T3,N0; T1–3,N1–3; T4a,N0–3.
Clinical trials are an alternative treatment for T3,N0; T1–3,N1–3; T4a,N0–3.
N0,N1, N2a–b, N3 are classifications for neck nodes.
Resection of primary and bilateral neck dissection are treatments for N0,N1, N2a–b, N3.
N2c (bilateral) is a classification for neck nodes.
Resection of primary and bilateral neck dissection are treatments for N2c (bilateral).
No adverse pathologic features are a consideration for treatment.
Consideration of RT is a treatment option for adverse pathologic features.
Systemic therapy/RT are treatments for adverse pathologic features.
RT is a treatment option for extranodal extension and positive margin.
Systemic therapy/RT are treatments for other risk features.
Re-resection is a treatment option if feasible and negative margins are achieved.
RT is a treatment option if negative margins are achieved.
Positive margin is a consideration for treatment.
Selected patients who decline surgery are a consideration for treatment.
Principles of Radiation Therapy are outlined in OR-A.
Principles of Systemic Therapy for Non-Nasopharyngeal Cancers are outlined in SYST-A.
For doses >70 Gy, some clinicians feel that the fractionation should be slightly modified to minimize toxicity.
Brachytherapy should be performed at centers where there is expertise in this modality.
The American Brachytherapy Society has recommendations for high-dose-rate brachytherapy for head-neck carcinomas.
GEC-ESTRO has recommendations for brachytherapy for head and neck squamous cell carcinomas.
The interval between HDR fractions should be at least 6 hours.
The planning target volume (PTV) includes high-risk areas such as primary tumor and involved lymph nodes.
The fractionation for high-risk areas is 66 Gy (2.2 Gy/fraction) to 70 Gy (2.0 Gy/fraction).
Concomitant boost accelerated RT is an option for high-risk areas.
Hyperfractionation is an option for high-risk areas.
Interstitial brachytherapy is considered for selected cases.
Low dose-rate (LDR) brachytherapy is an option.
High dose-rate (HDR) brachytherapy is an option.
Either intensity-modulated RT (IMRT) or 3D conformal RT (3D-CRT) is recommended for unresectable disease.
44–50 Gy in 3D-CRT and sequentially planned IMRT or 54–63 Gy with IMRT dose painting technique is suggested for radiation therapy.
The dose per fraction depends on the radiation therapy technique used.
Postoperative radiation therapy or concurrent systemic therapy/radiation therapy is recommended for high-risk patients.
The preferred interval between resection and postoperative radiation therapy is ≤6 weeks.
High-risk patients have adverse pathologic features such as positive margins.
High-risk patients receive 60–66 Gy of radiation therapy.
Low to intermediate risk patients receive 44–50 Gy to 54–63 Gy of radiation therapy.
IMRT is the preferred radiation therapy technique.
T1–T2 simple lip lesions are treated with postoperative radiation therapy as per non-melanoma skin cancers.
H&P should include documentation and quantification of tobacco use history.
H&P should include documentation and quantification of alcohol use and counseling.
All patients who currently smoke should be advised to quit smoking.
Those who formerly smoked should be advised to remain abstinent from smoking.
Image-guided needle biopsy of cystic neck nodes may offer better diagnostic yield than FNA by palpation alone for initial diagnosis.
For unresectable or metastatic disease where there is a plan for systemic therapy, a core biopsy would allow for ancillary immune-genomic testing.
Tumor human papillomavirus (HPV) testing by p16 immunohistochemistry is required.
H&P is required and should include a complete head and neck exam.
Biopsy of primary site or fine-needle aspiration of the neck is required.
CT with contrast and/or MRI with and without contrast of primary and neck is required.
EUA with endoscopy is recommended as clinically indicated.
FDG-PET/CT is recommended as clinically indicated.
Chest CT with or without contrast is recommended as clinically indicated.
Dental evaluation including Panorex is recommended as clinically indicated.
Nutrition, speech and swallowing evaluation/therapy, and audiogram are recommended as clinically indicated.
Smoking cessation counseling is recommended as clinically indicated.
Fertility/reproductive counseling is recommended as clinically indicated.
Screening for hepatitis B is recommended as clinically indicated.
Multidisciplinary consultation is recommended as clinically indicated.
T1–2,N0 or T0–2,N1 (single node ≤3 cm) and p16 (HPV)-positive patients have a specific treatment plan.
T0–2,N1 (single node >3 cm, or 2 or more ipsilateral nodes ≤6 cm), or T1–2,N2 or T3,N0–2 patients have a specific treatment plan.
Unresectable or unfit for surgery or metastatic (M1) disease initial presentation patients have a specific treatment plan.
Tumors in the base of tongue, posterior pharyngeal wall, and soft palate require consideration of bilateral neck treatment.
Tumors of the tonsil invading the tongue base require consideration of bilateral neck treatment.
pN0 and no adverse pathologic features is a condition.

Adverse pathologic features include extranodal extension, positive margins, close margins, pT3 or pT4 primary, pN2 or pN3 nodal disease, nodal disease in levels IV or V, perineural invasion, vascular invasion, and lymphatic invasion.
Systemic therapy/RT is a treatment option.

RT is a treatment option.

pN1 without other adverse pathologic features is a condition.

Adverse pathologic features include extranodal extension, positive margins, close margins, pT3 or pT4 primary, pN2 or pN3 nodal disease, nodal disease in levels IV or V, perineural invasion, vascular invasion, and lymphatic invasion.

Imaging plays an essential role in the clinical care of patients with head and neck cancer.
The proper selection and utilization of imaging studies is critical in caring for patients with head and neck cancer.
CT is performed with contrast.
CT imaging of the chest can be performed with or without contrast, as clinically indicated.
MRI is performed with and without contrast, unless contraindicated.
Imaging assessment of primary site can be performed with CT of the soft tissues of the neck or MRI of the neck.
CT is complementary to MRI for head and neck cancers.
CT is used to evaluate cortical bone erosion or periosteal invasion.
CT is used to evaluate cartilage invasion.
CT is used to evaluate bony erosion/destruction.
MRI is preferred over CT for evaluating the extent of bone marrow invasion.
MRI is preferred over CT for patients with extensive dental amalgam that may obscure the anatomy on CT.
MRI is preferred over CT for assessing skull base invasion and cranial nerve involvement.
MRI is preferred over CT for evaluating skull base or intracranial or orbital invasion, and to differentiate tumor from obstructed sinuses.
MRI is preferred over CT if there are cranial nerve symptoms or if radiographic perineural tumor spread is a possibility.
CT or MRI of the neck should image the anatomy from the skull base to the thoracic inlet to achieve complete evaluation of the primary and any nodal disease.
For certain conditions, such as involved lymph nodes in the low neck or cancers that frequently involve the upper mediastinum (such as thyroid cancer), the imaging should extend to the carina.
If imaging does not reveal an obvious primary, PET/CT should be ordered before EUA, biopsies, and tonsillectomy, to help identify potential primary sites before any intervention occurs.
FNA biopsy of metastatic nodes may be pathologically informative.
Image-guided (ultrasound [US] or CT) needle biopsy of cystic neck nodes may offer better diagnostic yield than FNA by palpation alone for initial diagnosis in this setting.
Panoramic dental x-ray is recommended for oral cavity cancers requiring mandibulotomy and/or mandibulectomy.

When postoperative RT is anticipated (including such sites as the lip, other oral cavity subsites, or the oropharynx), panoramic x-ray is part of a comprehensive pre-radiation dental evaluation to assess the health of the affected dentition and determine if pre-radiation dental procedures or extractions are needed.
NCCN provides guidelines for the initial workup of head and neck cancers.
Evaluation of lymph node metastases should be conducted with CT or MRI of the neck.
CT or MRI should be used for primary site evaluation.
For patients with multistation or lower neck nodal involvement or high-grade tumor histology, CT of the chest should be considered to assess for mediastinal lymph node metastases.
FDG-PET/CT is associated with higher sensitivity for both nodal and distant metastases.
For patients who are under consideration for a surgical primary approach, FDG-PET/CT is warranted for tumors approaching the midline.
FDG-PET/CT is beneficial for determining the surgical approach to the contralateral neck.
Patients who are scheduled for a definitive RT approach may benefit from the higher sensitivity of FDG-PET/CT for identifying involved lymph nodes.
For patients with locoregionally advanced cancer, FDG-PET/CT is preferred to evaluate for distant disease and thoracic metastases.
FDG-PET/CT cannot rule out brain metastasis.
For cancers where brain metastasis is a concern, contrast-enhanced brain MRI should be additionally obtained.
If FDG-PET/CT is not performed, CT of the chest should be performed to assess for presence of pulmonary metastases as well as mediastinal lymph node involvement.
Non-contrast CT of the chest can be sufficient to screen for lung parenchymal metastases.
Non-contrast CT of the chest is not adequate for assessment of mediastinal adenopathy.
Annual CT screening for lung metastasis is controversial following primary definitive treatment.
Annual chest CT can be considered for patients with a substantial smoking history or who are at high risk for lung metastases.
Historically, annual chest x-ray has been obtained but this is a much less sensitive test than CT.
If clinical concern for metastatic disease is confined to a specific anatomical area, the assessment of distant disease can be performed with directed CT or MRI examination.
The frequency of imaging tests depends on the planned treatment regimen and type of cancer.
FDG-PET/CT can explore distant disease or second primaries that may significantly impact choice of therapy.
PET/CT is preferred over PET scan alone.
PET/CT provides more accurate anatomical localization of abnormalities.
Short-term post-treatment imaging is recommended for patients who show signs of early recurrence or who are at high risk of early recurrence prior to starting adjuvant postoperative therapy.
CT and/or MRI should be obtained within 3–4 months after surgical treatment for patients with locoregionally advanced disease or with altered anatomy causing challenging physical exam assessment.
A CT or MRI scan may be obtained earlier, such as 4–8 weeks post-treatment or even immediately, in cases of concern for incomplete response.
US of the neck for targeted sampling of any suspicious tissues may also be helpful.
FDG-PET/CT should be performed within 3–6 months of definitive radiation or systemic therapy/RT for assessment of treatment response and to identify any residual tumor.
Early FDG-PET/CT scans before 12 weeks are associated with significant false-positive rates and should be avoided in the absence of signs of recurrence or progression.
The optimal timing of PET scans after radiation treatment appears to be at the 3- to 6-month window.
A negative PET at this time point predicts improved overall survival at 2 years.

FDG-PET/CT surveillance approach led to fewer neck dissections and considerable cost savings compared to a routine approach of planned post-treatment neck dissection in patients receiving definitive RT-based treatment of mucosal squamous cell carcinoma with AJCC 7th edition N2–N3 nodal disease.
The majority of recurrences after treatment of head and neck cancer occur in the first 2 years.
Surveillance can be challenging because of altered anatomy and/or fibrosis from surgery, radiation, and/or chemotherapy.
US, CT, MRI, and PET/CT all have unique advantages and disadvantages when used as surveillance imaging.
FDG-PET/CT may be the most sensitive of these modalities for surveillance imaging.
A 12-month PET has been shown to reveal recurrent or second primary cancers in approximately 10% of treated patients.
A 24-month FDG-PET/CT imaging revealed these findings in approximately 5% of treated cases.
Most cases of asymptomatic FDG-PET/CT lesion localization occur at distant sites.
A tailored approach to surveillance with attention to tumor type, stage, prognostic factors, symptomatology, and physical exam changes or restrictions is appropriate.
US of the neck is a well-established tool for nodal surveillance.
US is generally widely available, safe, fast, inexpensive, and an accurate modality for examination of the neck for any suspicious nodal disease.
Additional post-treatment imaging is indicated for worrisome or equivocal signs/symptoms.
Routine annual imaging may be indicated to visualize areas inaccessible to routine clinical examination.
All patients should be evaluated by a head and neck surgical oncologist prior to treatment.

The evaluation should review the adequacy of biopsy material, review staging and imaging to determine the extent of disease, exclude the presence of a synchronous primary tumor, assess current functional status, and evaluate for potential surgical options.

Pre-treatment evaluation should include consultations with a medical oncologist, radiation oncologist, dentist or oral maxillofacial surgeon, speech-language pathologist, dietitian, and reconstructive surgeon as appropriate.
Tumor staging for untreated patients is essential based on review of the head and neck diagnostic imaging studies and chest imaging as appropriate.
An office-based head and neck examination to include fiberoptic nasopharyngolaryngoscopy is indicated.
EUA is indicated to assess the tumor extent and to obtain a biopsy.
In the setting of metastatic carcinoma to the neck, an EUA is important to search for the putative primary site for diagnosis and treatment planning.
Participation in multidisciplinary team discussions regarding patient treatment options is important to maximize survival with preservation of form and function.

A prospective surveillance plan that includes adequate dental, nutritional, and health behavioral evaluation and intervention and any other ancillary evaluations is necessary for comprehensive rehabilitation.
Multidisciplinary evaluation and treatment should be coordinated and integrated prospectively by all disciplines involved in patient care before the initiation of any treatment.
For patients undergoing an operation, the surgical procedure, margins, and reconstructive plan should be developed and designed to resect all gross tumors with adequate tumor-free surgical margins.

The surgical procedure should rarely be modified based on any response observed as a result of prior therapy except in instances of tumor progression that mandate a more extensive procedure in order to encompass the tumor at the time of definitive resection.

Once the multidisciplinary team has established a proposed treatment regimen, the responsible physician and a member of the team should discuss the recommendations in detail with the patient to include the risks, benefits, and potential outcomes.
The patient should be offered the opportunity to participate in the final decision (shared decision-making).
Often, the patient’s first presenting sign of oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) is a neck mass.
The primary tumor is commonly small and asymptomatic and may not be detectable on inspection, palpation, fiberoptic examination, or imaging of the oropharynx.
It is incumbent upon the treating physician or surgeon to diligently search for and pathologically confirm the primary site.
The primary site is usually located in the base of tongue or tonsil.
Information obtained from a thorough workup evaluation is vital to enable the multidisciplinary team to develop a comprehensive and focused treatment plan individualized to the patient.
Identification of the primary site will either permit definitive transoral surgery to remove the primary disease or permit focused radiation, thus sparing adjacent sites in the oropharynx.
As therapy becomes more personalized, biomarker assessment of the primary tumor may be instrumental in determining a patient’s eligibility for a clinical trial or adjuvant therapy.
Cross-sectional imaging should be performed to facilitate identification of the primary site, followed by direct examination and confirmatory biopsies.
EUA and confirmatory biopsies for patients with suspected OPSCC should be performed before beginning therapy.
EUA may entail unilateral or bilateral biopsies of suspicious areas in the oropharynx.
Palatine tonsillectomies may reveal a small primary tumor.
Lingual tonsillectomy may be considered if biopsies and palatine tonsils are negative for tumor.
FNA biopsy of the neck mass, often performed under US guidance, will usually establish the diagnosis of metastatic carcinoma.
A definitive cytologic diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma is highly accurate.
Further assessment of immunostaining for p16 can support the diagnosis of HPV-associated OPSCC in the presence of an oropharyngeal primary tumor.

Tumor involvement of the pterygoid muscles, particularly when associated with severe trismus or pterygopalatine fossa involvement with cranial neuropathy, is associated with poor prognosis or function or with T4b cancer.
Gross extension of the tumor to the skull base is associated with poor prognosis or function or with T4b cancer.
Invasion of the common or internal carotid artery is associated with poor prognosis or function or with T4b cancer.
Direct extension of neck disease to involve the external skin is associated with poor prognosis or function or with T4b cancer.
Direct extension to mediastinal structures, prevertebral fascia, or cervical vertebrae is associated with poor prognosis or function or with T4b cancer.
Presence of subdermal metastases is associated with poor prognosis or function or with T4b cancer.
The resection of advanced tumors of the oral cavity, oropharynx, hypopharynx, larynx, or paranasal sinus will vary in extent depending on the structures involved.
The primary tumor should be considered surgically curable by appropriate resection using accepted criteria for adequate excision, depending on the region involved.
En bloc resection of the primary tumor should be attempted whenever feasible.
In-continuity neck dissection is necessary when there is direct extension of the primary tumor into the neck.
Resection should be planned based on the extent of the primary tumor as ascertained by clinical examination and careful interpretation of appropriate radiographic images.
For oral cavity cancers, as depth of invasion increases, the risk of regional metastases and the need for adjuvant elective neck dissection also increases.
Perineural invasion should be suspected when tumors are adjacent to motor or sensory nerves.
The goal is total cancer resection.

When gross invasion is present and the nerve can be resected without significant morbidity, the nerve should be dissected both proximally and distally and should be resected to obtain clearance of disease.
Frozen section determination of the proximal and distal nerve margins may prove helpful to facilitate tumor clearance.
Partial or segmental resection of the mandible may be necessary to adequately encompass the cancer with adequate tumor-free margins.
Adequate resection may require partial, horizontal, or sagittal resection of the mandible for tumors involving or adherent to mandibular periosteum.

Segmental or marginal resection should be considered in tumors that grossly involve mandibular periosteum or show evidence of direct tumor involvement of the bone at the time of operation or through preoperative imaging.
A Panorex may be useful for assessing mandibular height when a marginal or coronal mandibulectomy is a consideration.
In the edentulous patient due to mandibular atrophy that occurs over time, a partial mandibulectomy may not be possible.
The extent of mandibular resection will depend on the degree of involvement accessed clinically and in the operating room.
Medullary space invasion is an indication for segmental resection.
Frozen section examination of available marrow may be considered to guide resection.
For tumors of the larynx, the decision to perform either total laryngectomy or conservation laryngeal surgery will be decided by the surgeon and the patient.
The decision to perform either total laryngectomy or conservation laryngeal surgery should adhere to the principles of complete tumor extirpation with curative intent and function preservation.
Partial laryngeal surgery should be avoided if adjuvant RT is likely following surgery.
For T4 or N2–3 laryngeal cancers treated with surgery, consideration should be given to thyroidectomy for tumor clearance and clearance of central compartment pretracheal or paratracheal nodes.

Transoral robotic surgery (TORS) or laser-assisted resections of primary cancers of the larynx and pharynx are increasingly used approaches for cancer resection in selected patients with accessible tumors.
Oncologic principles are similar to open procedures.
Successful application of these techniques requires specialized skills and experience.
Postoperative hemorrhage can be a major and rarely life-threatening complication.
It is incumbent upon the TORS surgeon to use appropriate surgical strategies to diminish the risk of postoperative hemorrhage.
In oropharyngeal cancer cases, treatment selection should favor usage of fewest modalities necessary in order to minimize treatment-related toxicity and preserve function.
Avoid triple modality treatment when possible.
Patients with fixed nodes are not appropriate candidates for upfront definitive surgery.
An overarching goal of oncologic surgery is complete tumor resection with histologic verification of tumor-free margins.
Margin assessment may be done in real time by frozen section or by assessment of formalin-fixed tissues.
Tumor-free margins are an essential surgical strategy for diminishing the risk for local tumor recurrence.
Positive margins increase the risk for local relapse and are an indication for postoperative adjuvant therapy.
Clinical pathologic studies have demonstrated the significance of close or positive margins and their relationship with local tumor recurrence.
When there is an initial cut-through with an invasive tumor at the surgical margin, obtaining additional adjacent margins from the patient may also be associated with a higher risk for local relapse.
Obtaining additional margins from the patient is subject to ambiguity regarding whether the tissue taken from the surgical bed corresponds to the actual site of margin positivity.
If positive surgical margins are reported, re-resection and/or adjuvant therapy should be considered in selected patients.
Frozen section margin assessment is always at the discretion of the surgeon and should be considered when it will facilitate complete tumor removal.
The achievement of adequate wide margins may require resection of an adjacent structure in the oral cavity or laryngopharynx.
Adequate resection is defined as clear resection margins with at least enough clearance from the gross tumor to obtain clear frozen section and permanent margins.
For glottic cancers, a 1- to 2-mm margin is considered adequate.
In transoral endoscopic and robotic approaches for oropharynx cancers, margins of 1.5–2.0 mm may be acceptable.
The details of resection margins should be included in the operative dictation.
The margins may be assessed on the resected specimen or alternatively from the surgical bed with proper orientation.
Adequacy of the margins may vary by site.
For a glottic cancer 1- to 2-mm margins are sufficient but inadequate for an invasive carcinoma of the oral tongue.
There is no universal definition for what constitutes a clear/close margin.
Distance in mm to achieve clinically acceptable margins is influenced by tumor primary site, histology, and HPV status in oropharyngeal cancer and following neoadjuvant therapy.
The previous universally followed definition of adequate margin (5 mm in final histopathology) has been disputed.
A positive margin is defined as carcinoma in situ or as invasive carcinoma at the margin of resection.
If carcinoma in situ is present and if additional margins can be obtained that is the favored approach.
Carcinoma in situ should not be considered an indication for concurrent postoperative systemic therapy/RT.
The primary tumor should be marked in a fashion adequate for orientation by the surgical pathologist.
The primary tumor should be assessed histologically for depth of invasion and for distance from the invasive portion of the tumor to the margin of resection.
The pathology report should be template-driven and describe how the margins were assessed.
The report should provide information regarding the primary specimen to include the distance from the invasive portion of the tumor to the peripheral and deep margin.

If the surgeon obtains additional margins from the patient, the new margins should refer back to the geometric orientation of the resected tumor specimen with a statement by the pathologist that this is the final margin of resection and its histologic status.
The neck dissection should be oriented or sectioned in order to identify levels of lymph nodes encompassed in the dissection.
Reconstruction of surgical defects should be performed using conventional techniques at the discretion of the surgeon.
Primary closure is recommended when appropriate but should not be pursued at the expense of obtaining wide, tumor-free margins.
Reconstructive closure with locoregional flaps, free-tissue transfer, or split-thickness skin or other grafts with or without mandibular reconstruction is performed at the discretion of the surgeon.
A two-team approach is advisable to improve efficiency and address both oncologic and reconstructive goals.
The surgical management of cranial nerves VII, X, XI, and XII is influenced by the preoperative clinical function of the nerve.
When the nerve is functioning, thorough efforts should be made to preserve the structure and function of the nerve.
The surgeon should leave no gross residual disease when preserving the nerve.
Adjuvant postoperative radiation or systemic therapy/RT is generally prescribed when a microscopic residual or gross residual tumor is suspected.
Direct nerve invasion by a tumor and/or preoperative paralysis of the nerve may warrant segmental resection at the discretion of the surgeon.
Tumor-free margins should be ensured throughout the remainder of the procedure during segmental resection.
Nerve grafting may be performed at the discretion of the surgeon during segmental resection.
The surgical management of regional lymphatics is dictated by the extent of the tumor at initial tumor staging.
Patients undergoing surgery for resection of the primary tumor will undergo dissection of the ipsilateral side of the neck that is at greatest risk for metastases.
Tumor sites that frequently have bilateral lymphatic drainage often should have both sides of the neck dissected.
For patients with tumors at or approaching the midline, both sides of the neck are at risk for metastases, and bilateral neck dissections should be performed.

Patients with advanced lesions involving the anterior tongue, floor of the mouth, or alveolus that approximate or cross the midline should undergo contralateral selective/modified neck dissection as necessary to achieve adequate tumor resection.
Elective neck dissection should be based on risk of occult metastasis in the appropriate nodal basin.
For oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma, SLN biopsy or the primary tumor depth of invasion is currently the best predictor of occult metastatic disease and should be used to guide decision-making.
For tumors with a depth greater than 3 mm, elective dissection should be strongly considered if RT is not already planned.
Recent randomized trial evidence supports the effectiveness of elective neck dissection in patients with oral cavity cancers greater than 3 mm in depth of invasion.
For a depth less than 2 mm, elective dissection is only indicated in highly selective situations.
For a depth of 2–4 mm, clinical judgment must be utilized to determine appropriateness of elective dissection.
Elective dissections are generally selective, preserving all major structures, unless operative findings dictate otherwise.
The type of neck dissection is defined according to preoperative clinical staging and is determined at the discretion of the surgeon.
The type of neck dissection is based on the initial preoperative staging.
For N0, selective neck dissection is performed.
For N1–N2a–c, selective or comprehensive neck dissection is performed.
For N3, comprehensive neck dissection is performed.
Level VI neck dissections are performed for certain primary sites as required to resect the primary tumor and any clinically evident neck nodes.
Elective dissection depends on primary tumor extent and site.
For advanced glottic and hypopharyngeal cancers treated with primary surgery, a level VI dissection and hemithyroidectomy to total thyroidectomy are appropriate.

For primary subglottic tumors or glottic cancers with significant subglottic extension, a level VI dissection with unilateral or total thyroidectomy is considered appropriate based on the extent of the primary tumor.
Parathyroid glands should be preserved in situ or auto transplanted as indicated.
Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLN biopsy) is an alternative to elective neck dissection for identifying occult cervical metastasis in patients with early oral cavity carcinoma.
SLN biopsy requires technical experience and judgment for successful execution of lymphatic mapping and SLN.
SLN biopsy has advantages including reduced morbidity and an improved cosmetic outcome.
Rates of detection of sentinel nodes in excess of 95% have been widely reported.
Patients with metastatic disease in their sentinel nodes must undergo a completion neck dissection.
Patients without metastatic disease in their sentinel nodes may be observed.
Accuracy of sentinel node biopsy for nodal staging of early oral carcinoma has been tested extensively in multiple single-center studies and two multi-institutional trials.
The pooled estimate of sensitivity of sentinel node biopsy is 0.93.
The negative predictive values of sentinel node biopsy range from 0.88 to 1.6.
Available evidence points towards comparable survival outcomes between sentinel node biopsy and elective neck dissection.
Sentinel node biopsy is a technically demanding procedure.
Procedural success rates for sentinel node identification depend on technical expertise and experience.
Accuracy of detecting occult lymphatic metastasis depends on technical expertise and experience.
Sufficient caution must be exercised when offering sentinel node biopsy as an alternative to elective neck dissection.
Accuracy of sentinel node biopsy has been found to be lower for floor-of-mouth cancer than for other locations such as the tongue.
Cancers of certain locations such as upper gingiva and hard palate may not lend themselves well technically to sentinel node biopsy.
Occult cervical metastases are uncommon in early lip cancer.
SLN biopsy has been shown to be feasible and effective in patients with lip cancers deemed to be at high risk of metastases generally based on tumor size or depth.
Resectable primary cancers should be re-resected with curative intent if feasible.
Recurrences in a previously treated neck should undergo surgery as well.
Neck disease in an untreated neck should be addressed by formal neck dissection or modification depending on the clinical situation.
Non-surgical therapy may also be utilized as clinically appropriate.
All patients should have regular follow-up visits to assess for symptoms and possible tumor recurrence, health behaviors, nutrition, dental health, and speech and swallowing function.
Tumor evaluations must be performed by specialists skilled in head and neck clinical examination.
The frequency of evaluation is summarized elsewhere in the NCCN Guidelines for Head and Neck Cancers.
All patients should be evaluated by a radiation oncologist prior to treatment.
The evaluation should review staging and imaging to determine the extent of disease.
The evaluation should exclude the presence of a synchronous primary tumor.
The evaluation should assess functional status.
The evaluation should evaluate for potential RT options.
Radiation oncologists should participate in multidisciplinary team discussions regarding patient treatment options.
The goal of the discussions is to maximize survival with preservation of form and function.
A prospective surveillance plan should be developed for patients.
The plan should include adequate dental, swallowing, nutritional, and health behavior evaluation and intervention.
The plan may include other ancillary evaluations that would provide for comprehensive rehabilitation.
Target delineation and optimal dose distribution require experience in head and neck imaging.
Target delineation and optimal dose distribution require a thorough understanding of patterns of disease spread.
Standards for target definition, dose specification, fractionation, and normal tissue constraints are still evolving.
Published contouring guidelines are referenced for patients who have not been operated upon.
IMRT or other conformal techniques may be used as appropriate depending on the stage, tumor location, physician training, and available physics support.
FDG-PET/CT or MRI with contrast can be used for fusion in treatment planning.
Advanced RT technologies such as IMRT, tomotherapy, VMAT, IGRT, and PBT may offer clinically relevant advantages in specific instances.
These technologies can spare important organs at risk, such as the brain, brain stem, cochlea, and others.
These technologies can decrease the risk for late, normal tissue damage while still achieving the primary goal of local tumor control.
The demonstration of clinically significant dose-sparing of these organs at risk reflects best clinical practice.
Target definition and delineation and treatment delivery verification require careful monitoring to avoid the risk of tumor geographic miss.
Initial diagnostic imaging with contrast-enhanced CT, MRI, FDG-PET/CT, and other imaging modalities facilitate target definition.
Image guidance is required to provide assurance of accurate daily delivery.
Anatomical changes may necessitate repeat diagnostic imaging and replanning.
IMRT is preferred in reducing long-term toxicity in oropharyngeal, nasal cavity, paranasal sinus, salivary gland, and nasopharyngeal cancers.
IMRT reduces the dose to salivary glands, temporal lobes, auditory structures, and optic structures.
IMRT is preferred for thyroid cancers because of its ability to spare the larynx, brachial plexus, and esophagus.
Helical tomotherapy and VMAT are advanced forms of IMRT.
PBT is especially important for patients whose primary tumors are periocular in location and/or invade the orbit, skull base, and/or cavernous sinus.
PBT is especially important for patients who are being treated with curative intent and/or who have long life expectancies following treatment.
Proton therapy can be considered when normal tissue constraints cannot be met by photon-based therapy.
Proton therapy can be considered when photon-based therapy causes compromise of standard radiation dosing to tumor or postoperative volumes.
A number of ways exist to integrate IMRT or PBT, target volume dosing, and fractionation.
The SIB technique uses differential “dose painting” for each fraction of treatment throughout the entire course of radiation.
The SIB technique is commonly used in the conventional and the “6 fractions/wk accelerated” schedule.
The sequential technique typically delivers the initial phase followed by the high-dose boost volume phase using 2–3 separate dose plans.
The sequential technique is commonly applied in standard fractionation and hyperfractionation.
Palliative radiation should be considered in the advanced cancer setting when curative-intent treatment is not appropriate.
There is no general consensus for appropriate palliative RT regimens in head and neck cancer.
Palliative RT should be considered for relief or prevention of locoregional symptoms if the RT toxicities are acceptable.
RT regimens should be tailored individually.
Severe RT toxicities should be avoided when treatment is for palliation.
One recommended RT regimen is 50 Gy in 20 fractions.
Another recommended RT regimen is 37.5 Gy in 15 fractions.
Yet another recommended RT regimen is 30 Gy in 10 fractions.
Another recommended RT regimen is 30 Gy in 5 fractions with 2 fractions/week with ≥3 days between the 2 treatments.
Another recommended RT regimen is 44.4 Gy in 12 fractions, in 3 cycles.
Reirradiation with 3D-CRT, SBRT, PBT, or IMRT may be considered for patients with head and neck cancers.
The area in consideration for reirradiation should not overlap with the previously radiated volume, or the prior radiotherapy should have been more than 6 months from the appearance of new disease.
In certain rare circumstances, reirradiation with intraoperative RT (IORT) or brachytherapy may be considered in high-volume centers with expertise in these techniques.
There are dose constraints for the Larynx.
The mean dose for the Larynx is less than 35 Gy.
There are dose constraints for the Glottis.
The mean dose for the Glottis is less than 45 Gy.
The categories of evidence and consensus for induction therapy vary depending on the site of the cancer.
Adverse pathologic features include extranodal extension and/or positive margins or close margins.
Cisplatin is a preferred regimen for postoperative systemic therapy and radiotherapy.
Cisplatin is category 1 for high-risk non-oropharyngeal cancers.
Docetaxel is a useful regimen in certain circumstances, especially if cisplatin is ineligible.
Docetaxel is a useful regimen in certain circumstances, especially if cisplatin is ineligible.
Docetaxel/cetuximab is a useful regimen in certain circumstances, especially if cisplatin is ineligible and there is extranodal extension and/or positive margins.
Weekly carboplatin plus concurrent radiotherapy is a preferred regimen for systemic therapy and radiotherapy following induction therapy or for recurrent/persistent disease.
Weekly cisplatin plus concurrent radiotherapy is a preferred regimen for systemic therapy and radiotherapy following induction therapy or for recurrent/persistent disease.
Weekly cetuximab plus concurrent radiotherapy is a useful regimen in certain circumstances.
Docetaxel/cisplatin/5-FU is a preferred regimen for induction/sequential systemic therapy.
Paclitaxel/cisplatin/infusional 5-FU is an other recommended regimen for induction/sequential systemic therapy.
Carboplatin/paclitaxel/cetuximab is a useful regimen in certain circumstances.
Etoposide/cisplatin is a useful regimen for newly diagnosed T3, T4a ethmoid sinus tumor.
Docetaxel/cisplatin/fluorouracil is a useful regimen for newly diagnosed T3, T4a ethmoid sinus tumor.
High-dose cisplatin is a preferred regimen for primary systemic therapy plus concurrent radiotherapy.
Carboplatin/infusional 5-FU is a preferred regimen for primary systemic therapy plus concurrent radiotherapy.
Weekly cisplatin is an other recommended regimen for primary systemic therapy plus concurrent radiotherapy.
Carboplatin/paclitaxel is a useful regimen in certain circumstances.
5-FU/hydroxyurea is a useful regimen in certain circumstances.
Cetuximab is a useful regimen in certain circumstances.
Cisplatin/infusional 5-FU is a useful regimen in certain circumstances.
Cisplatin/paclitaxel is a useful regimen in certain circumstances.
Carboplatin/etoposide plus concurrent radiotherapy is a useful regimen for select ethmoid/maxillary sinus cancers.
Cisplatin/etoposide plus concurrent radiotherapy is a useful regimen for select ethmoid/maxillary sinus cancers.
Cyclophosphamide/doxorubicin/vincristine followed by radiotherapy-based treatment is a useful regimen for select ethmoid/maxillary sinus cancers.
The choice of systemic therapy should be individualized based on patient characteristics.
Next-generation sequencing genomic profiling, including testing for combined positive score, may be considered to guide patient treatment options.
The preferred chemoradiotherapy approach for fit patients with locally advanced disease remains concurrent cisplatin and radiotherapy.
Cisplatin-based induction chemotherapy can be used, followed by radiation-based locoregional treatment.
Cisplatin-based induction chemotherapy followed by high-dose, every-3-week cisplatin chemoradiotherapy is associated with toxicity concerns.
After induction chemotherapy, multiple options can be used for the radiation-based portion of therapy.
Pembrolizumab/platinum (cisplatin or carboplatin)/5-FU is a preferred regimen for first-line therapy.
Pembrolizumab is a preferred regimen for first-line therapy for tumors that express PD-L1 with CPS ≥1.
Nivolumab is a recommended regimen for subsequent-line therapy if disease progression occurs on or after platinum therapy.
Pembrolizumab is a recommended regimen for subsequent-line therapy if disease progression occurs on or after platinum therapy.
Cetuximab/platinum (cisplatin or carboplatin)/5-FU is a combination regimen.
Cisplatin/cetuximab is a combination regimen.
Cisplatin or carboplatin/docetaxel is a combination regimen.
Cisplatin/5-FU is a combination regimen.
Cisplatin or carboplatin/docetaxel/cetuximab is a combination regimen.
Cisplatin or carboplatin/paclitaxel/cetuximab is a combination regimen.
Pembrolizumab/platinum (cisplatin or carboplatin)/docetaxel is a combination regimen.
Pembrolizumab/platinum (cisplatin or carboplatin)/paclitaxel is a combination regimen.
Cisplatin is a single agent.
Carboplatin is a single agent.
Paclitaxel is a single agent.
Docetaxel is a single agent.
5-FU is a single agent.
Cetuximab/nivolumab is a regimen for squamous cell carcinoma.
Cetuximab/pembrolizumab is a regimen for squamous cell carcinoma.
Cisplatin/etoposide or carboplatin/etoposide is a regimen for select ethmoid/maxillary sinus cancers.
Paclitaxel/cetuximab is a regimen.
Docetaxel/cetuximab is a regimen.
Pembrolizumab is a regimen for MSI-H, dMMR, or TMB-H tumors.
Cisplatin/pemetrexed is a regimen for PS 0–1.
Gemcitabine/paclitaxel is a regimen.
Nivolumab/ipilimumab is a regimen for CPS ≥20 and first-line therapy only.
The choice of systemic therapy should be individualized based on patient characteristics.

Most patients with head and neck cancer lose weight and are nutritionally compromised.
Nutritional management is important in patients with head and neck cancer to improve outcomes and minimize treatment-related complications.
A registered dietitian and a speech language/swallowing therapist should be part of the multidisciplinary team for treating patients with head and neck cancer.
Bar Ad V, Weinstein G, Dutta PR, et al published a study on gabapentin for the treatment of pain syndrome related to radiation-induced mucositis in patients with head and neck cancer in 2010.

Leenstra JL, Miller RC, Qin R, et al published a phase III, randomized, double-blind trial on doxepin rinse versus placebo in the treatment of acute oral mucositis pain in patients receiving head and neck radiotherapy in 2014.

Sio TT, Le-Rademacher JG, Leenstra JL, et al published a randomized clinical trial on the effect of doxepin mouthwash or diphenhydramine-lidocaine-antacid mouthwash vs placebo on radiotherapy-related oral mucositis pain in 2019.
Close monitoring of nutritional status is recommended in patients who have significant weight loss or difficulty swallowing.
All patients should be evaluated for nutritional risks and receive nutrition counseling by a registered dietitian.
Nutrition interventions, such as feeding tubes or intravenous nutrition support, may be indicated for patients with nutritional risks.
Pre- and post-treatment functional evaluation, including nutritional status, should be undertaken using subjective and objective assessment tools.
All patients should receive dietary counseling with the initiation of treatment, especially with radiotherapy-based treatments.
Regular follow-up with the registered dietitian should continue at least until the patient has achieved a nutritionally stable baseline following treatment.
A formal speech and swallowing evaluation at baseline is recommended for patients with speech and/or swallowing dysfunction or patients whose treatment is likely to affect speech and/or swallowing.
Patients with ongoing abnormal function should be seen regularly by speech-language pathologists.
Dysphagia and swallowing function can be measured by clinical swallowing assessments or by videofluoroscopic swallowing studies.
Patient evaluations should also include assessment for any changes in speech and communication; changes in taste; and assessment for xerostomia, pain, trismus, lymphedema, and fibrosis.
Follow-up with the speech-language pathologist should continue at least until the patient has achieved a stable baseline following treatment.
Pain from oral mucositis should be assessed and pregabalin, gabapentin, doxepin, or diphenhydramine/lidocaine/antacid mouthwash may be prescribed as clinically indicated.
Ehrsson YT, Langius-Eklöf A, and Laurell G wrote about nutritional surveillance and weight loss in head and neck cancer patients.
Locher JL, Bonner JA, Carroll WR, et al wrote a comprehensive review of prophylactic percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube placement in treatment of head and neck cancer.

Langius JA, van Dijk AM, Doornaert P, et al found that more than 10% weight loss in head and neck cancer patients during radiotherapy is independently associated with deterioration in quality of life.
The panel does not recommend prophylactic PEG or NG tube placement in patients with very good PS and without significant pretreatment weight loss, significant airway obstruction, or severe dysphagia.

Prophylactic feeding tube placement should be strongly considered for patients with severe weight loss prior to treatment, ongoing dehydration or dysphagia, anorexia, or pain interfering with the ability to eat/drink adequately, significant comorbidities, severe aspiration, or mild aspiration in patients who are older or have compromised cardiopulmonary function, or patients for whom long-term swallowing disorders are likely.

Caloric intake, treatment-related side effects, and change in body weight should be monitored weekly during treatment for those who did not warrant prophylactic PEG or NG tube placement pre-treatment.

Reactive feeding tube placement should be considered if two or more of the following criteria apply: inadequate food intake, weight loss of 5% or more in 1 month, severe mucositis, odynophagia, dysphagia, or aspiration, or age >60 years.
Patients who may have feeding tube placement should be encouraged to intake orally if they can swallow without aspiration or any other compromises.
Alterations in swallowing function can occur long after treatment and should be monitored for the lifetime of the patient.
Bossola M wrote a narrative review of nutritional intervention in head and neck cancer patients undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
Talwar B, Donnelly R, Skelly R, et al wrote about nutritional management in head and neck cancer.
Sachdev S, Refaat T, Bacchus ID, et al found that age is the most significant predictor of requiring enteral feeding in head-and-neck cancer patients.
Radiation therapy (RT) to the head and neck causes xerostomia and salivary gland dysfunction.
Xerostomia and salivary gland dysfunction dramatically increase the risk of dental caries and its sequelae.
Dental caries and its sequelae include dentoalveolar infection and osteoradionecrosis.
RT also affects the dental hard tissues, which increases their susceptibility to demineralization.
Demineralization occurs in the presence of xerostomia, microbial changes following RT, and changes to a more cariogenic diet.
IMRT and salivary gland-sparing techniques are associated with dose-dependent recovery of salivary function over time.
IMRT and salivary gland-sparing techniques are associated with reduced risk for dental caries long term for some patients.
Radiation-related caries and other dental hard tissue changes can appear within the first 3 months following RT.
The goal of Pre-RT Oral/Dental Evaluation is patient education regarding oral and dental complications of RT and need for adherence with preventive protocols.
Patient education includes both oral and written information.
One principle of oral/dental evaluation and management is the effect on salivary glands.
Dry mouth strategies include increased hydration, minimizing ingestion of caffeinated products and alcohol, and using salivary substitutes.
Salivary substitutes include gels containing lysozyme, lactoferrin, peroxidase, and supersaturated calcium phosphate solutions.
Another dry mouth strategy is using an alcohol-free mouthwash, such as stabilized 0.1% chlorine dioxide oral rinse.
Salivary stimulation can be achieved through gustatory stimulants or cholinergic agonists.
Gustatory stimulants include xylitol chewing gum, sorbitol/malic acid lozenges, and xylitol lozenges.
Cholinergic agonists include pilocarpine and cevimeline.
One principle of oral/dental evaluation and management is dental caries prevention.
Diet counseling is part of dental caries prevention.
Meticulous oral hygiene is part of dental caries prevention.
Meticulous oral hygiene includes brushing teeth twice daily, flossing or using an interdental cleaner daily, and using an alcohol-free mouthwash twice daily.
High potency topical fluoride is part of dental caries prevention.
High potency topical fluoride can be applied through daily 1.1% NaF gel or SNF2 gel, brush on or in custom dental trays, or daily 1.1% NaF dentifrice.
Fluoride varnish application three times per year is also part of dental caries prevention.
Calcium phosphate artificial saliva rinse is part of dental caries prevention.
Regular frequent dental evaluations are necessary to detect dental disease.
Candidiasis prevention and control is part of oral/dental evaluation and management.
Candidiasis prevention and control includes topical therapy with anti-fungal lozenges or suspensions.
Systemic antifungal therapy may be necessary if candidiasis is refractory to topicals.
An infectious disease consult may be necessary for systemic antifungal therapy.
One principle of oral/dental evaluation and management is the effect on bone in irradiated field.
A pre-RT dental evaluation is necessary to determine the need for dental extractions.
Dental extractions should be completed at least 2 weeks prior to the start of RT.
The long-term prognosis of teeth and patient motivation should be considered in determining the need for dental extractions.
The oncology team should be contacted if any future extractions or surgery in irradiated field are necessary.
One principle of oral/dental evaluation and management is the effect on masticatory muscles, which can lead to trismus.
Maintaining range of motion is necessary to prevent trismus.
Tongue blades and gentle stretching can help maintain range of motion.
Custom mouth-opening devices can be used for rehabilitation of trismus and jaw motion.
The treatment plan includes eliminating potential sources of infection.
The treatment plan includes performing extractions at least 2 weeks before the start of RT.
The treatment plan includes treating active dental caries and periodontal disease.
The treatment plan includes using silicone guards to minimize radiation backscatter if patients have metal restorations.
The treatment plan includes prescribing potent topical fluoride for daily use.
The duration of use of potent topical fluoride is to be determined by periodic caries risk assessment over time.
The treatment plan includes scheduling a return visit for re-evaluation and reinforcement of the preventive protocol for 6–12 weeks after completion of RT.
The treatment plan includes evaluating for oral candidiasis and treating appropriately with antifungal agents.
The principles of oral/dental evaluation and management include managing xerostomia during cancer therapy.
The principles of oral/dental evaluation and management include preventing trismus of masticatory muscles during cancer therapy.
The principles of oral/dental evaluation and management include evaluating for oral candidiasis and treating as clinically indicated during cancer therapy.
The goals of oral/dental management post-treatment include managing xerostomia.
The goals of oral/dental management post-treatment include preventing and minimizing trismus.
The goals of oral/dental management post-treatment include preventing and treating dental caries.
The goals of oral/dental management post-treatment include preventing and managing post-radiation osteonecrosis.
Stabilized 0.1% chlorine dioxide oral rinse is recommended in the guidelines.
The goals of oral/dental management post-treatment include preventing and managing oral candidiasis.
Consultation with the treating radiation oncologist is recommended before considering implants or extraction.
Dental recall visit interval is based on risk and is at least once every 6 months.
Dental recall visit interval may be more frequent for those with xerostomia or for those with new caries or lesions following radiotherapy.

T1 is a classification for tumors ≤2 cm with depth of invasion (DOI) ≤5 mm.
T2 is a classification for tumors ≤2 cm, with DOI >5 mm or tumors >2 cm and ≤4 cm, with DOI ≤10 mm.
T3 is a classification for tumors >2 cm and ≤4 cm, with DOI >10 mm or tumors >4 cm, with DOI ≤10 mm.
T4 is a classification for moderately advanced or very advanced local disease.
T4a is a classification for moderately advanced local disease.
Tumor >4 cm, with DOI >10 mm or tumor invades adjacent structures only is classified as T4a.
T4b is a classification for very advanced local disease.
Tumor invades masticator space, pterygoid plates, or skull base and/or encases the internal carotid artery is classified as T4b.
DOI is depth of invasion and not tumor thickness.
NX is a classification for regional lymph nodes that cannot be assessed.
N0 is a classification for no regional lymph node metastasis.
N1 is a classification for metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or smaller in greatest dimension ENE(–).
N2 is a classification for metastasis in a single ipsilateral node larger than 3 cm but not larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension and ENE(–).
N2 is a classification for metastases in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension and ENE(–).
N2 is a classification for metastases in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension, and ENE(–).
N2a is a classification for metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node larger than 3 cm but not larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension, and ENE(–).
N2b is a classification for metastases in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension, and ENE(–).
N2c is a classification for metastases in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension, and ENE(–).
N3 is a classification for metastasis in a lymph node larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension and ENE(−).
N3 is a classification for metastasis in any node(s) and clinically overt ENE(+).
N3a is a classification for metastasis in a lymph node larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension and ENE(−).
N3b is a classification for metastasis in any node(s) and clinically overt ENE(+).
A designation of “U” or “L” may be used for any N category to indicate metastasis above the lower border of the cricoid (U) or below the lower border of the cricoid (L).
A designation of “U” or “L” may be used for any N category to indicate metastasis above the lower border of the cricoid (U) or below the lower border of the cricoid (L).
Clinical and pathological ENE should be recorded as ENE(−) or ENE(+).
The American College of Surgeons published the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, Eighth Edition in 2017.
The AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, Eighth Edition is the original source for the TNM Staging Classification for the Oral Cavity.
Distant Metastasis is classified as M in the TNM Staging Classification for the Oral Cavity.
M0 means that there is no distant metastasis.
M1 means that there is distant metastasis.
Histologic Grade is classified as G in the TNM Staging Classification for the Oral Cavity.
GX means that the histologic grade cannot be assessed.
G1 means that the histologic grade is well differentiated.
G2 means that the histologic grade is moderately differentiated.
G3 means that the histologic grade is poorly differentiated.
Prognostic Stage Groups are classified in the TNM Staging Classification for the Oral Cavity.
Stage 0 means that the tumor is Tis, N0, and M0.
Stage I means that the tumor is T1, N0, and M0.
Stage II means that the tumor is T2, N0, and M0.
Stage III means that the tumor is T1 or T2, N1, and M0; or T3, N0 or N1, and M0.
Stage IVA means that the tumor is T1, N2, and M0; or T2, N2, and M0; or T3, N2, and M0; or T4a, N0, N1, or N2, and M0.
Stage IVB means that the tumor is any T, N3, and M0; or T4b, any N, and M0.
Stage IVC means that the tumor is any T, any N, and M1.
TX is a classification for primary tumor that cannot be assessed.
T0 means no tumor is identified, but EBV-positive cervical node(s) involvement is present.
Tis is a classification for carcinoma in situ.
T1 is a classification for tumor confined to nasopharynx, or extension to oropharynx and/or nasal cavity without parapharyngeal involvement.
T2 is a classification for tumor with extension to parapharyngeal space, and/or adjacent soft tissue involvement (medial pterygoid, lateral pterygoid, prevertebral muscles).
T3 is a classification for tumor with infiltration of bony structures at skull base, cervical vertebra, pterygoid structures, and/or paranasal sinuses.

T4 is a classification for tumor with intracranial extension, involvement of cranial nerves, hypopharynx, orbit, parotid gland, and/ or extensive soft tissue infiltration beyond the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid muscle.
NX is a classification for regional lymph nodes that cannot be assessed.
N0 is a classification for no regional lymph node metastasis.

N1 is a classification for unilateral metastasis in cervical lymph node(s) and/or unilateral or bilateral metastasis in retropharyngeal lymph node(s), 6 cm or smaller in greatest dimension, above the caudal border of cricoid cartilage.
N2 is a classification for bilateral metastasis in cervical lymph node(s), 6 cm or smaller in greatest dimension, above the caudal border of cricoid cartilage.
N3 is a classification for unilateral or bilateral metastasis in cervical lymph node(s), larger than 6 cm in greatest dimension, and/or extension below the caudal border of cricoid cartilage.
M0 is a classification for no distant metastasis.
M1 is a classification for distant metastasis.
