Patients with discordant OPSCC (p16-/HPV+ or p16+/HPV-) had a significantly worse prognosis than patients with p16+/HPV+ OPSCC.
Patients with discordant OPSCC (p16-/HPV+ or p16+/HPV-) had a significantly better prognosis than patients with p16-/HPV16- OPSCC.
The detection of HPV-16 mRNA E6*I is currently regarded as the most reliable detection method for the definitive HPV-16 association in oropharyngeal carcinomas.
A meta-analysis of 24 studies showed a sensitivity of 94% for p16-IHC alone compared to the detection of viral E6/E7 transcripts as a reference.
A meta-analysis of 24 studies showed a specificity of 83% for p16-IHC alone compared to the detection of viral E6/E7 transcripts as a reference.
The 8th edition of the TNM classification introduces a different, p16-associated approach with a reclassification of tumour stages and N-status.
If an OPSCC is p16-positive, not only pT1N0M0 tumours are subsumed under stage I, but now also pT1.2 pN0.1 tumours.
Stage II even allows pT1.2 pN2 and pT3 pN0.1 tumours, compared to only pT2N0 previously.
Stage III includes pT3 pN2 and pT4 pN0-2 (8th edition TNM 2017).
The staging of p16-positive OPSCC is differentiated clinically and pathologically.
cN2 is stage II and pN2 is stage III.
The N category is categorized according to the number of positive lymph nodes (pN1: 1-4; pN2: ≥ 5).
The tumour stages according to the TNM classification and the R status are the most important prognostic factors in oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma.
The tumour stages according to the TNM classification and the R status should be indicated in all cases with reference to the current 8th edition.
Additional parameters on the primary tumour should be recorded: Lymphatic vessel, venous and perineural sheath invasion and degree of differentiation.
There is a strong consensus on the importance of recording the tumour stages according to the TNM classification and the R status.
Clinical cervical lymph node status is classified as cN.
Clinical criteria for cN apply to non-surgically treated patients without cervical lymph node dissection.
Clinical assessment for cN summarizes information from physical examination, imaging, and fine needle aspiration.
NX is a classification of nodal status that cannot be determined.
N0 is a classification of no regionally enlarged or metastasized lymph nodes.
N1 is a classification of metastasis in single ipsilateral node, ≤3 cm, and no extranodal spread, ECS(-).
N2 is a classification of metastasis in single ipsilateral node, >3 cm, or metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, or metastases in bilateral or contralateral nodes.
N2a is a classification of metastasis in single ipsilateral node, >3 cm and ≤6 cm, and ECS(-).
N2b is a classification of metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, all ≤6 cm, and ECS(-).
N2c is a classification of metastases in bilateral or contralateral nodes, all ≤6 cm, and ECS(-).
N3 is a classification of metastases in one node, >6 cm, or metastases in a node with clinically obvious ECS(+).
N3a is a classification of metastases in one node, >6 cm, and ECS(-).
N3b is a classification of metastases in a node with clinically obvious ECS(+).
Pathological cervical lymph node status is classified as pN.
Pathologic criteria for pN apply to surgically treated patients with cervical lymph node dissection.
Pathologic criteria for pN require multiple whole lymph nodes available for microscopic evaluation.
NX is a classification of nodal status that cannot be determined in pN.
N0 is a classification of no metastases in the examined lymph nodes in pN.
N1 is a classification of metastasis in single ipsilateral node, ≤3 cm, and no extranodal spread, ECS(-) in pN.
N2 is a classification of metastasis in single ipsilateral node, >3 cm, or metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, or metastases in bilateral or contralateral nodes in pN.
N2a is a classification of metastasis in single ipsilateral node, >3 cm and ≤6 cm, and ECS(-) in pN.
N2a is also a classification of metastasis in single ipsilateral node, ≤3 cm, and ECS(+) in pN.
N2b is a classification of metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, all ≤6 cm, and ECS(-) in pN.
N2c is a classification of metastases in bilateral or contralateral nodes, all ≤6 cm, and ECS(-) in pN.
N3 is a classification of metastases in one node, >6 cm, or metastases in a node with clinically obvious ECS(+) in pN.
N3a is a classification of metastases in one node, >6 cm, and ECS(-) in pN.
cM0 means no evidence of distant metastases.
cM1 means high probability of distant metastases present (high evidence in imaging).
pM1 means existing distant metastases, histologically confirmed.

N3b is a category of metastasis in single ipsilateral node, >3 cm, and ECS(+); or multiple ipsilateral, contralateral, or bilateral nodes with ECS(+); or single contralateral node of any size and ECS(+).
Distant metastases (M) are classified into cM0, cM1, and pM1.
TNM 8th edition is a reference for TNM staging.
T1, T2, T3, and T4 are categories of primary tumour.
TX means primary tumour cannot be determined.
Tis means carcinoma in situ.
T1 means tumour limited to a subunit of the hypopharynx and/or tumour ≤ 2 cm in greatest extension.
T2 means tumour extends into the adjacent subunits of the hypopharynx or the adjacent neighbouring structures and/or tumour > 2 cm and ≤ 4 cm without fixation of the hemilarynx.
T3 means tumour >4 cm, or clinical fixation of the hemilarynx, or extension into the oesophageal mucosa.
T4 means moderately or very advanced disease.

The TNM classification defines T4a as moderately advanced disease with infiltration of the thyroid cartilage, cricoid cartilage of the larynx, hyoid bone, thyroid gland, oesophageal muscles, or prelaryngeal soft tissue.
The TNM classification defines T4b as far advanced disease with envelopment of the carotid artery or infiltration of mediastinum or prevertebral fascia.
The R classification generally applies to squamous cell carcinomas in the head and neck region.
The R classification describes the presence of residual tumour after therapy, usually after surgical therapy.
The R classification provides important information on any further treatment that may be necessary and on the patient's prognosis.
R0 is defined as carcinomas that have been resected in sano.
An R1 situation is present if the tumour microscopically reaches one of the preparation margins directly.
An R2 situation is present if the tumour remains in the patient macroscopically.
An RX situation exists if the resection margin cannot be reliably assessed histomorphologically.
The histopathology report should indicate the tumour location and size.
The histopathology report should indicate the pTN status.
The histopathology report should indicate the histological tumour type according to the current WHO classification.
The histopathology report should indicate the local tumour extent and infiltrated structures.
The histopathology report should indicate the number of LKs examined.
The histopathology report should indicate the number of affected LKs.
The histopathology report should indicate the largest diameter of the lymph node metastases.
The histopathology report should indicate tumour growth beyond the capsule (ECS, ENE).
The histopathology report should indicate lymph vessel/venous invasion and perineural invasion.
The histopathology report should indicate the presence of an in situ component (with size).
The histopathology report should indicate the differentiation of the tumour according to the established grading scheme.
The histopathology report should indicate the distance to the lateral and basal resectate margins for all relevant resection margins as well as for the invasive and in situ components in mm.
The histopathology report should indicate the R classification.
The histopathology report should indicate the p16 expression status (positive, negative) for oropharynx only.
Tumour resection should be performed as an en bloc resection of the primary tumour.
The treatment decision is influenced by the tumour location and size.
The treatment decision is influenced by the histological tumour type according to the current WHO classification.
The treatment decision is influenced by the local tumour extent and infiltrated structures.
The treatment decision is influenced by lymph node metastases separated according to level and side.
The number of lymph nodes examined is a parameter in the pathological assessment.
The number of affected lymph nodes is a parameter in the pathological assessment.
The largest diameter of the lymph node metastases is a parameter in the pathological assessment.
Tumour growth beyond the capsule is a parameter in the pathological assessment.
Lymph vessel/venous invasion and perineural invasion are parameters in the pathological assessment.
The presence of an in situ component and its size are parameters in the pathological assessment.
The differentiation of the tumour according to the established grading scheme is a parameter in the pathological assessment.
The distance to the lateral and basal resectate margins for all relevant resection margins and for the invasive and in situ components in mm is a parameter in the pathological assessment.
The R classification is a parameter in the pathological assessment.
The indication of the p16 expression status is a parameter in the pathological assessment.
If the findings are unclear, the biopsy should be repeated after consultation with the pathologist.
In the case of resectates, the tumour specimen should be sent to the pathologist by the surgeon with a clear description of the anatomical topography.
In the case of a neck dissection, the levels must be marked separately or sent in portions as individual specimens for pathohistological examination.
The cut edges on the resectate can be examined by means of a frozen section according to clinical relevance.
It is preferable to send the resectate 'en bloc' and have the surgeon or pathologist take a frozen section of the resectate margins.
The surgeon or pathologist should take a frozen section of the resectate margins.
The procedure of sending the resectate 'en bloc' preserves the integrity of the specimen in the best possible way.
This procedure allows the most reliable statement on the R status.

Transoral robotic surgery (TORS) or laser microsurgery (TLM) resections of primary tumours of the oropharynx and hypopharynx are increasingly used approaches for cancer resection in selected patients with accessible tumours.
Oncologic principles are similar to open procedures.
If safe en bloc resection is not possible, it is appropriate to send separate margin sections.
The separate margin sections should ideally also be sent to the pathologists as frozen sections.
Locoregional metastasis of the primary tumour to the cervical lymph nodes is a reliable negative predictor of prognosis.
The more lymph nodes involved, the less favourable the course of the disease.
Involvement of the caudal levels (IV and V) and growth beyond the capsule have a negative impact on the prognosis.
The histopathological findings of the neck dissection specimens should include the side of the neck.
The histopathological findings of the neck dissection specimens should include the cleared levels.
The histopathological findings of the neck dissection specimens should include the total number of lymph nodes with the number of affected lymph nodes per level.
The histopathological findings of the neck dissection specimens should include the diameter of the largest lymph node metastasis.
The histopathological findings of the neck dissection specimens should include additionally removed structures.
The histopathological findings of the neck dissection specimens should include - if present - information on growth that exceeds the lymph node capsule (extra nodal extension, ENE).
A clear margin is defined as the distance from the invasive tumour front that is 5 mm or more from the resected margin.
The goal of oncological surgery is complete tumour resection with histological evidence of tumour-free margins.
Tumour-free margins are a basic principle of surgical strategy to reduce the risk of local tumour recurrence.
Positive margins increase the risk of local recurrence and are an indication for postoperative adjuvant therapy.
Classic clinical-pathological studies have shown the significance of narrow or positive margins and their correlation with local tumour recurrence.
The removal of frozen sections is generally recommended.

A recent multicentre Italian study showed that in patients in whom R0 resection was verified intraoperatively by frozen sections, the local control rate was twice as high as in those without frozen section verification.
Frozen section assessment is a quality indicator of surgical and pathological procedures and their effectiveness.
If there is an initial incision through an invasive tumour at the surgical margin, additional harvested adjacent margins from the patient may mean a higher risk of local recurrence.
If positive surgical margins are reported, a repeat resection should be considered if possible.
If positive surgical margins are reported, adjuvant therapy should be considered if repeat resection is not reasonably possible.
The patient's prognosis is not worsened by an initial R1, or close R0 situation, which leads to a final stable R0 situation through resection at the correct site.
Assessment of frozen section margins is always at the surgeon's discretion.
Assessment of frozen section margins should be considered if it facilitates complete removal of the tumour.
Achieving sufficiently wide margins may require resection of an adjacent structure in the oral cavity.

The surgical safety distance is defined by current international consensus as clean resection margins with at least sufficient distance from the gross tumour to obtain a clear frozen section and permanently free margins.
Clean resection margins can often mean 1.0-1.5 cm of visible and palpable normal mucosa.
A frozen section examination of the margins is usually performed intraoperatively and when a resection line is not clear due to indistinct tumour margins or when residual disease is suspected.
Residual disease is suspected in cases of soft tissue, cartilage, carotid artery or mucosal irregularities.
For transoral endoscopic and robotic approaches for oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal cancers, margins of 1.5-2.0 mm may be acceptable.
Margins of 1.5-2.0 mm would in principle be considered 'narrow or closed' and are considered too narrow for certain sites, such as the base of the tongue.
A clear resection margin is defined as the distance from the invasive tumour front that is 5 mm or more from the resected margin.
There is international agreement on the definition of a clear resection margin, which is reflected in the current NCCN guidelines.
For hypopharyngeal carcinomas with diffuse, partially submucosal spread, particularly towards the oesophagus, the 5 mm safety margin should be regarded as the absolute minimum.
The 5 mm safety margin can be generously extended to 1 cm for safe resection according to international consensus.
A narrow margin is defined as the distance from the invasive tumour front to the resected margin that is less than 2-5 mm depending on the anatomical site affected.
A positive margin is defined as carcinoma in situ or invasive carcinoma at the resected margin.
If carcinoma in situ is present and if additional clean margins can be achieved by resection, this is the preferred approach.
Carcinoma in situ should not be considered an indication for concomitant postoperative systemic therapy/RT.
Tumour grading appears to have a greater prognostic role than previously assumed.

In the aforementioned multicentre Italian study, the group of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinomas showed a statistically significant and clinically relevant difference in 5-year tumour relapse-free survival and OS compared to the group of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinomas.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: blood in the saliva.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: hoarseness.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: difficulty speaking and breathing.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: persistent foreign body sensation, especially on one side.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: pain radiating into the ear.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: dysphagia and/or pain when swallowing.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: unclear coughing up blood.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: swelling of the throat.
Immediate referral to an appropriate specialist should be made for any of the following findings if they persist for more than four weeks: foetor ex ore.
Appropriate endoscopic/mirror examinations must be performed.
The symptoms vary greatly depending on the location of the carcinoma.
Hypopharyngeal and tongue base carcinomas are characterized by difficulty swallowing, a lumpy sensation and swallowing pain (radiating into the ear).
Changes in voice and hoarseness may also occur, and in the later stages, breathing may also be impaired.
If the above-mentioned symptoms persist for more than four weeks, a specialist should be consulted.
Initially, there may be swelling of the lymph nodes in the neck, which can be confused with inflammatory diseases such as pharyngo-laryngitis or lymphadenitis.

Progressive tumour growth leads to increasing functional impairments such as considerable voice and breathing disorders as well as difficulties in swallowing and nutritional disorders with weight loss.
Severe pain develops, radiating to the entire head and neck region.
In up to 40% of patients, the cervical lymph nodes may already be affected at the time of initial diagnosis despite a clinically unremarkable neck.
Immediate referral to a specialist should be made for the following findings if they persist for more than three weeks: blood in the saliva.
Immediate referral to a specialist should be made for the following findings if they persist for more than three weeks: hoarseness.
Immediate referral to a specialist should be made for the following findings if they persist for more than three weeks: difficulty speaking and breathing.

The clinical examination for suspected oropharyngeal or hypopharyngeal carcinoma includes specific ENT examinations following a general medical history, full body examination and recording of relevant comorbidities.
The clinical examination involves endoscopy of the oral cavity, oro- and hypopharynx and larynx in the phonation and respiratory position.
A 90° magnifying laryngoscope should be used for the clinical examination.
Surface anaesthesia of the pharynx usually improves the examination options.
Particular attention must be paid to vocal fold mobility during the clinical examination.

A phoniatric examination to assess the vibration behaviour of the vocal folds, particularly in hypopharyngeal carcinomas with incipient vocal fold fixation with the aid of a stroboscope, is recommended.
Systemic tumour seeding, especially in the lungs, is also possible.
Multilocular tumour growth occurs when several regions of the pharynx and larynx are affected at the same time.

Endoscopy of the neighbouring mucosal areas, e.g. with a 90° loupe laryngoscope or with a flexible rhino-pharyngo-laryngoscope, is part of the primary clinical diagnosis of oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma.

During panendoscopy under anaesthesia, the tracheo-bronchial system and the oesophagus can also be examined in order to rule out further secondary carcinomas and to determine the exact extent of the tumour by palpation and endoscopy while the patient is relaxed.
Suspect lesions distant from the primary tumour should be biopsied separately.
A mapping biopsy in inconspicuous areas of the mucosa may also be useful.
The clinical examination also includes palpation of the neck to detect lymph node metastases.
Palpation of the neck is supplemented by ultrasound and CT/MRI if neoplasia is suspected.
Newer endoscopic procedures such as coherence tomography, autofluorescence and electronic chromoendoscopy (narrow band imaging) can also be used.
The clinical examination includes the systematic recording of comorbidities and so-called 'frailty' (a state of decreased physical function and mobility).
CT (contrast-enhanced) or MRI should be performed to determine the local extent of an oropharyngeal or hypopharyngeal carcinoma.
The tumour biopsy should only be performed after the slice imaging has been performed to avoid distortions of the contrast agent behaviour on the primary tumour.
If artifacts are expected in the oropharynx due to metal in the oral cavity, MRI should be preferred to CT for the assessment of the primary tumour.
In locoregionally advanced tumours, an FDG-PET/CT should be performed to exclude distant metastases before function-restricting therapeutic measures.
The entire region from the base of the skull to the upper thoracic aperture should be examined with CT or MRI to determine the N category.
Ultrasound-guided fine-needle biopsy can improve the diagnostic specificity of lymph node staging in the neck.
FDG-PET-CT/MRI can improve the diagnostic specificity and sensitivity of lymph node staging in the neck.
In patients with confirmed oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma, a chest CT should be performed to rule out pulmonary tumour involvement.
As part of the primary diagnosis, imaging should be performed to rule out liver metastases.
In patients with suspected recurrence in the head and neck region, PET-CT can be performed if this cannot be confirmed or ruled out with CT and/or MRI.
A sonography of the head and neck region may be indicated to justify the indication for further measures in patients with suspected recurrence in the head and neck region.
Clinical examination and imaging measures such as ultrasound diagnostics, CT or MRI, chest X-ray or chest CT are part of the diagnosis of oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma.
Panoramic tomography should be available to assess the dental status, also with regard to possible radiotherapy.
A meta-analysis included 2 studies focusing on T-stage, 1 study focusing on T- and N-stage and 3 studies focusing on N-stage.
The pooled sensitivity/specificity was 89.3% / 89.5% for PET/CT.
The pooled sensitivity/specificity was 71.6% / 78.0% for conventional cross-sectional imaging (CT and MRI).
CT and MRI are of similar accuracy for the diagnosis of cervical lymph node metastases.
CT and MRI are clearly superior to clinical examination for the diagnosis of cervical lymph node metastases.
CT appears to be slightly more reliable than MRI for the visualization of infrahyoid lymph node metastases.
MRI appears to visualize the nodes along the vascular nerve sheath better than CT.
MRI is recommended for routine diagnostics to determine soft tissue infiltration and lymph node status.
In a direct comparative study, MRI performed better than CT for the determination of cervical lymph node metastases in terms of sensitivity, specificity and accuracy.
The diagnostic accuracy of MRI can be increased in combination with FDG-PET.
FDG-PET does not allow a reliable statement to be made about the dignity of the detected lymph nodes.
PET is much less informative as a stand-alone method than in combination with CT or MRI.
PET should always be performed as a hybrid procedure (PET-CT or PET-MRI).
The accuracy of CT, MRI and ultrasound in the assessment of lymph node metastases is comparable.
In the case of borderline large lymph nodes on CT or MRI without signs of central necrosis, a targeted ultrasound-guided fine needle biopsy or FDG-PET can increase diagnostic accuracy.
The value of PET-CT for the diagnosis of cervical lymph nodes is controversial due to the high number of false positive findings.
PET-CT is considered particularly unsuitable for lymph nodes less than 10 mm in size.

In the 8th edition of the TNM classification, the determination of extranodal tumour growth (ENE, extranodal extension) was excluded in pretherapeutic staging for HPV16/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinomas.
The determination of extranodal tumour growth (ENE, extranodal extension) remains highly valid for postoperative adjuvant therapy decisions.
In a meta-analysis that included 2478 patients from 22 studies, the pooled sensitivity/specificity was 0.73/0.83 (CT) and 0.60/0.96 (MRI).
The pooled specificity for HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers was lower than for HPV-negative oropharyngeal cancers (0.74 vs. 0.87).
Ultrasonography is a standard method for assessing the cervical lymph nodes.
Ultrasonography has a higher sensitivity and specificity than CT or MRI in individual studies.
Ultrasonography is an inexpensive method that can often be repeated during follow-up.
The accuracy and informative value of ultrasonography depend heavily on the experience of the examiner.
Few studies have looked at the sensitivity of ultrasound-guided fine-needle biopsy (FNB) to determine pathologic lyphatic node dignity.
The sensitivity of ultrasound-guided fine-needle biopsy (FNB) is low for small tumours with a clinical N0 neck.
Ultrasound-guided fine-needle biopsy (FNB) can be helpful for preoperative confirmation of dignity in palpable LKs.
Ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration has a higher specificity than CT for palpable lumps.
A combination of the examination modalities CT, MRI and PET-CT does not lead to any significant improvement.
Despite its high sensitivity, PET-CT has no improved diagnostic value for primary tumours and therefore cannot replace the clinical examination.
A chest CT is generally recommended as part of the diagnosis of the primary tumour.
Chest X-ray overview is obsolete for staging.
Both LK metastases and a second pulmonary carcinoma can be detected by CT with high sensitivity and specificity.
In patients with suspected recurrence in the head and neck region, sonography of the neck regions may also be indicated.
CT proved to be the safest screening method for detecting distant metastases.
CT detected either metastasis or a synchronous second carcinoma in approximately 11% of cases.
Chest CT is recommended as an important imaging modality for primary staging in all patients with head and neck tumours.
Despite the very low overall incidence of liver metastases, liver imaging is recommended as an obligatory part of pre-therapeutic staging.

If a metastasis is detected in a single lymph node of category N2b or N2c, or if an involved lymph node measures more than 3 cm in maximum diameter (N2a or N3), there is a higher risk of distant metastases.
A whole-body FDG-PET-CT is recommended as an alternative to CT thorax/abdomen to rule out or objectify distant metastases.
The sensitivity for the detection of distant metastases is 96.8%.
The specificity for the detection of distant metastases is 95.4%.
The positive predictive value for the detection of distant metastases is 69.8%.
The negative predictive value for the detection of distant metastases is 99.6%.
FDG-PET showed a higher reliability with a sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 61-71% than CT and/or MRI for recurrence detection.
After combined radio-chemotherapy, surveillance using FDG-PET-CT should precede a planned salvage neck dissection in node-positive patients with oropharyngeal or hypopharyngeal carcinoma.
If the FDG-PET-CT is negative, the salvage neck dissection can be omitted.
Mehanna et al. conducted a prospective randomized study on the role of PET-CT surveillance in node-positive patients.
Breik et al. favours PET/CT for the follow-up of patients with oral cavity, oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinomas in the 3-6 month period after the end of therapy.
Panendoscopy should be performed as part of the primary diagnosis of oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinomas.
Panendoscopy is a central part of primary diagnostics for a more precise diagnosis of the extent of the primary tumour and for the detection of secondary carcinomas.
The frequency of clinically occult secondary carcinomas varies considerably in the literature from 1% to over 10%.
There are indications that the frequency of secondary carcinomas depends on the stage of the primary tumour.

Patients with oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma who smoke and regularly drink large amounts of alcohol have a probability that these noxious substances have also caused carcinomas or precursor lesions in other regions of the upper airways and oropharynx.
Stöckli et al. dealt intensively with the topic of secondary carcinomas in 2001.
Stöckli et al. described 16.2% secondary carcinomas in 358 patients examined in 2001.
40% of synchronous secondary carcinomas were found in the primary tumour of the oral cavity and pharynx in Stöckli et al.'s study.
20% of synchronous secondary carcinomas were detected exclusively by panendoscopy in Stöckli et al.'s study.
Haughey et al. found 14% of secondary carcinomas with the highest prevalence in oral cavity, oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinomas in 1992.
Di Martino et al. evaluated the tumour registry of the ENT clinic at RWTH Aachen and found 7.7% metachronous carcinomas in 843 patients with head and neck carcinomas in 2000.
15.3% of metachronous carcinomas were in the lungs in Di Martino et al.'s study.
Figures of 0.8% are given for the explicit occurrence of second tumours in the oesophagus in oral cavity carcinoma.
Koo et al. observed second carcinomas for small oral cavity and pharyngeal carcinoma (tongue T1-2) patients with existing tobacco and alcohol consumption in 14.5-16.3% of patients.
In the few never smokers/drinkers, the second carcinoma rate was 0% in Koo et al.'s study.
Hung et al. found an odds ratio of 55.3 for synchronous oesophageal cancer in patients with oral cavity/pharyngeal cancer compared to the normal population group in 2000.
Hung et al. strongly recommended performing panendoscopy in routine primary diagnostics in 2000.
Sharma et al. saw 5.56% second cancers (predominantly in the hypopharynx) in 234 patients in Germany in 2018.
Davidson et al. concluded on the basis of a 154-patient series that routine panendoscopy was unnecessary for 2.6% of secondary cancers in 2000.
The 'Tumour Assessment and Staging: UK National Multidisciplinary Guidelines' recommends panendoscopy under general anaesthesia as part of the primary diagnosis in England.

The authors of the 'Tumour Assessment and Staging: UK National Multidisciplinary Guidelines' critically concede that although there is a documented proportion of secondary cancers for panendoscopy in the literature, according to a review by McGarey et al. the proportion of secondary cancers has decreased in the last three decades.
McGarey et al. reviewed that the proportion of secondary cancers has decreased in the last three decades.

Rigid oesophagoscopy in particular should only be performed in patients with primary tumours in whom an increased incidence of secondary cancers has been described (oropharynx and hypopharynx are addressed) according to McGarey et al.'s review.

The anaesthesia- and surgery-associated risk of panendoscopy is considered to be subordinate or negligible in relation to the more precise initial diagnosis and thus undisputed added value for the patient.
The NCCN Guidelines, Version 2.2022, explicitly recommend performing panendoscopy under general anaesthesia as part of the pre-therapeutic staging examination.
Clinical experience has shown that the imaging of small and early, superficially located squamous cell carcinomas of the mucous membranes of the upper aerodigestive tract is often inadequate.
Panendoscopy is considered more important than imaging when it comes to determining the exact extent of the tumour and visualizing metachronous secondary carcinomas.
A distinction must be made between panendoscopy and the targeted biopsy endoscopy performed for histological verification in the case of apparent abnormalities in the mirror examination or imaging.
The proposal that panendoscopy should only be performed in cases where there is a history of increased risk is not expedient in the light of the literature.
Many head and neck tumour patients dissimulate in their medical history as part of the primary diagnosis and to a large extent provide unreliable information on tobacco and alcohol consumption.
Panendocopy should remain an obligatory diagnostic component even for p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinomas, as combined risk factor constellations are predominant, particularly in Germany.
Second cancers can occur synchronously or metachronously.
Synchronous secondary carcinomas may already be clinically apparent at the time of the manifestation of oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma during the ear, nose and throat examination.
Panendoscopy is suitable for the exclusion or detection of clinically occult secondary carcinomas and their precursors and cannot be replaced by imaging.
Panendoscopy is one of the mandatory diagnostic measures to be performed prior to a therapeutic decision on histologically proven oropharyngeal or hypopharyngeal carcinoma.
Panendoscopy is usually performed together with endoscopy of the expected tumour region, which also includes a tissue sample (biopsy).

Palpation of the oral cavity, in particular the tongue, the base of the tongue and the accessible pharyngeal region under anaesthesia during the initial phase of maximum muscle relaxation is considered an important step during panendoscopy.
Panendoscopy addresses the entire upper airway and alimentary canal, i.e. the entire oral cavity, the entire naso-, oro- and hypopharynx and the larynx are inspected.
The tracheobronchial system and the oesophagus can be inspected during a biopsy.
The oral cavity and oropharynx can be inspected directly without an endoscope.
The mucosa, base of the tongue, hypopharynx and larynx should be assessed with an endoscope.
Laryngoscopes, such as the 'Kleinsasser tube', are usually used for inspecting the larynx.
Endoscopy of the tracheobronchial system can be performed using rigid endoscopes with different angles.
Oesophagoscopy can also be performed with a rigid, preferably pneumatic oesophagoscope.
Performing oesophagoscopy with a flexible endoscope is recommended by some authors due to the possible complications of rigid endoscopy.
Rigid endoscopy is advantageous for inspecting the postcricoid area.
Tracheobronchoscopy can also be performed optically with flexibility.
In the presence of hypopharyngeal carcinoma with laryngeal involvement, microlaryngoscopy is of particular importance.
Microlaryngoscopy can define the extent of the primary tumour.
Superficial mucosal changes that cannot be detected by imaging can be easily recognized during microlaryngoscopy.
The piriform sinus is often compressed in sectional imaging.
The exact extent of the tumour can often not be precisely determined if there is surrounding oedema.
Endoscopic 'stretching' of the piriform sinus region is of great additional diagnostic benefit.
Microlaryngoscopy can determine whether the entire larynx can be adjusted endoscopically.
A mapping biopsy may also be useful in these situations.
The findings concerning the primary tumour extension obtained during panendoscopy including palpation are entered or drawn into a prefabricated pictogram.
It is advisable to check the resectability and enter this on the document.
In the event of resectability, the exact surgical procedure should be determined.
The sample for biopsy should be taken from the edge of the tumour and, if possible, centrally from the base of the tumour.
The removal of a tissue sample and its subsequent histopathological examination is an essential prerequisite for the initiation of tumour-specific treatment.
A biopsy is usually performed as part of panendoscopy.
Biopsy treatment is carried out before a tissue sample is taken.
A tissue sample should preferably be taken from the peripheral area of the tumour.
A tissue sample should not be taken from the necrotic centre only.
It is desirable to collect tumour bases from non-necrotic areas where feasible.
The usual form of biopsy for macroscopically clear, advanced tumours is an incisional biopsy with microshears or sharp forceps (Blakesley).
An excisional biopsy should only be performed for circumscribed lesions without deep infiltration.
Excisional biopsy is particularly suitable for older patients in order to avoid a second procedure under anaesthesia in the case of in sano resection (R0).
Areas of mucosa that are suspicious for the presence of a precursor lesion should also be biopsied.
A so-called brush biopsy is not recommended.
Photo documentation of the tumour during panendoscopy under anaesthesia and prior to sampling is recommended.
Photo documentation of the tumour during panendoscopy under anaesthesia and prior to sampling is of great benefit in the subsequent treatment decision.
If the histology findings are unexpectedly negative, the biopsy should be repeated at least once.
P16 immunohistology can be used in many scenarios as a surrogate marker of HPV infection in squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.
A case should be considered positive if more than 70% of the tumour cells express p16 at least moderately in nuclear and cytoplasmic levels.
Different p16 antibodies show slightly different positivity rates, but result in comparable expression patterns overall.
The inter-observer variability in the evaluation appears to be rather low.
HPV detection using molecular methods can be used confirmatively in cases with unclear p16 staining or other limitations in the predictivity of a p16 immunohistology for an HPV association.
The variety of molecular methods available is large, and no single one can be recommended here as being particularly sensitive.
The method used should be checked regularly in inter-laboratory tests, it seems desirable to include positive controls.
PD-L1 positivity plays a role in the stratification of squamous cell carcinomas of the head and neck region for treatment with immune checkpoint inhibitors.

Determination of PD-L1 as part of the primary diagnosis is useful, but according to the current approval situation, it can only be recommended as mandatory in the diagnosis of recurrence or distant metastasis.
As distant metastases can often not be confirmed with biopsy, the PD-L1 status obtained during primary diagnosis is a valuable marker for the initiation of first or second-line therapy.
Of four established different PD-L1 scoring algorithms, two are currently relevant for approval for squamous cell carcinomas of the head and neck region: the CPS and the TPS.
CPS describes the proportion of PD-L1-positive tumour and immune cells in relation to all tumour cells, multiplied by 100.
CPS is given as a pure number, not as a percentage.
PD-L1-positive cells include tumour cells, lymphocytes, and macrophages.
CPS is calculated by dividing the number of PD-L1-positive cells by the total number of vital tumour cells and multiplying by 100.
TPS is the proportion of tumour cells that are PD-L1-positive.
TPS is given as a percentage.
TPS is calculated by dividing the number of PD-L1-positive tumour cells by the total number of vital tumour cells and multiplying by 100.
CPS and TPS cannot be converted into each other mathematically.
CPS and TPS should both be requested diagnostically when asking about the PD-L1 status.
The IC score indicates the percentage of the tumour area that is occupied by PD-L1-positive tumour-infiltrating immune cells.
The TAP score can also be considered.
The IC score and the TAP score are currently less relevant.
The evaluation according to IC or TAP score currently plays no role in treatment decisions for oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma in the first or second line.
The interchangeability of different assay systems for PD-L1 measurement appears to be broadly possible in different entities.
Evaluator variability is acceptable according to current studies.
Participation in quality assurance programs seems advisable.
Sentinel lymph nodes are those lymph nodes that are closest to the tumour in the lymph drainage area of a malignant tumour.
If tumour cells have already been carried into these lymph nodes with the lymph flow and have led to a metastasis, they are called sentinel lymph nodes.
Metastasis in sentinel lymph nodes indicates that further metastases are likely to be found in downstream lymph nodes.
If no metastases are found in the removed sentinel lymph node, there is a low probability that further lymph node metastases are present.
The sentinel lymph node technique is a clinically established technique for breast carcinoma, prostate carcinoma and melanoma.
The oral cavity is considered to be an important primary tumour site that can be considered for meaningful sentinel lymph node biopsy (SNB).
Liu et al. conducted a meta-analysis of 66 studies with 3566 tongue cancer patients.
The sensitivity of SLN biopsy with regard to the detection of lymph node metastasis is stated as 0.87 [0.85-0.89].
Considering only the studies in which patients with negative SLN were followed up and the false negatives were detected over the course, the sensitivity is 0.85 [0.82-0.88].
SLN biopsy is equivalent in terms of survival after conventional neck dissections for small squamous cell carcinomas (T1/T2).
There are advantages for SLN biopsy in terms of postoperative quality of life and functionality.
There are advantages for SLN biopsy in terms of lower complication rates.

According to the S3 Guideline on Oral Cavity Carcinoma, SLN biopsy can be offered for early, transorally resectable oral cavity carcinomas that do not require a transcervical approach in the same procedure.
If the sentinel lymph node is positive and detection is uncertain, a complete neck dissection should be performed.
Van den Bosch et al. conducted a meta-analysis of 19 studies and 377 patients.
The sensitivity and negative predictive value of SLN biopsy were estimated at 0.93 (95% CI: 0.86-0.96) and 0.97 (95% CI: 0.94-0.98).
According to the authors, the accuracy of the SNB justifies its place in the diagnosis of patients with oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinomas.
Further meta-analyses underline the high sensitivity and specificity in oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma.
Werner et al. showed that SNB is safest when several detected lymph nodes (up to three) are removed.
Oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma can impair functions such as voice production, swallowing and breathing.
The patient must be given a detailed explanation of the possible disorders that may arise after a specific therapy.
The initial informative discussion with the patient and their relatives is important so that they can decide on the right therapy for them.
The patient will often follow the doctor's recommendation, so it is all the more important to explain the consequences of the treatment.
If information is provided on the probability of recovery, this should be given as absolute (and not relative) frequencies where possible.
The probable risks and consequences of non-therapy should also be explained.
The patient should be informed about the prognosis with regard to voice production.
The patient should be informed about the prognosis with regard to breathing.
The patient should be informed about the prognosis with regard to swallowing.
The patient should be informed about visible changes to the face and neck after the therapeutic procedure.
The patient should be informed about possibly stigmatizing changes to the face and neck after the therapeutic procedure.
The patient should be informed about whether a permanent tracheostomy or a temporary tracheostomy is being performed.
The patient should be informed about whether a tracheostomy tube needs to be worn.
Aspiration is not an insignificant problem in operations in the oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal region and must be explained to the patient.
The patient must be informed about the possible impairment of swallowing function.
The patient must be informed about the possible impairment of voice production.
The majority of oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinomas are caused by noxious substances.
Noxious substances include smoking and alcohol abuse.
The connection between noxious substances and oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinomas must be clearly explained to the patient.
The treatment of oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma should be carried out on an interdisciplinary basis.

The treatment should be carried out after coordination of each individual case within tumour boards involving the specialist disciplines of otorhinolaryngology, oral and maxillofacial surgery, radiation oncology, oncology, pathology and radiology.
The patient should be informed in detail and repeatedly about their illness, treatment options and subsequent disorders.
Patients with oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma should be examined by an experienced dentist to determine their dental status before starting treatment.
Therapy breaks beyond the planned weekend breaks should be avoided during radiotherapy.
Radiotherapy should not have therapy breaks beyond the planned weekend breaks.
The treatment recommendations for oropharyngeal and hypopharyngeal carcinoma are compiled on the basis of the 8th edition of the TNM classification.
HPV/p16-positive tumours have a significantly better prognosis.
Registry studies show that in HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinomas, the results of radiochemotherapy are still positive for relatively high tumour burden up to cT3 tumours.

Radiochemotherapy results are equivalent to the primary surgical approach with regard to all important outcomes in HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinomas with bilateral lymph node involvement (N2).
The guideline provides information on oncological and functional endpoints for HPV/p16-negative tumours with a smaller tumour burden (cT1-2 cN0).
The treatment recommendations do not differ between HPV/p16+ and HPV/p16-.
The maximum therapy includes either primary surgical therapy with adjuvant radiochemotherapy with cisplatin or primary radiochemotherapy with cisplatin.

There is evidence that the results of primary surgical therapy (+/- adjuvant radio/radiochemotherapy) and primary radio/radiochemotherapy do not differ significantly in terms of overall survival, relapse-free survival, locoregional relapse rate and distant metastasis-free survival in patients with HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinoma in stages I-II (UICC 8th edition).

Patients with HPV/p16 positive oropharyngeal carcinoma in stages I-II (UICC 8th edition) should receive either primary surgical therapy (+/- adjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy) or primary radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy.

Patients with HPV/p16 negative oropharyngeal carcinoma in stages I, II (cT1N0, cT2N0; UICC 8th edition) should receive either primary surgical therapy (+/- adjuvant radio- or radiochemotherapy) or primary radio- or radiochemotherapy.

In the case of a primary surgical approach, a transoral procedure for primary tumour resection should be preferred to a procedure with a transcervical approach for T1 and T2 tumours of the oropharynx, HPV/p16 positive and negative.
The transoral procedure for primary tumour resection includes transoral laser microsurgery (TLM) and transoral robotic surgery (TORS).

If a transoral surgical technique is chosen for a laterally located tumour with an increased risk of postoperative bleeding, consideration should be given to clipping/bandaging the arterial vessels supplying the tumour side transcervically.
Clipping/bandaging the arterial vessels supplying the tumour side transcervically can reduce the intraoperative and postoperative risk of bleeding.
Primary radiochemotherapy and surgery followed by adjuvant radiochemotherapy were equivalent in patients with stage II disease.
In patients with stage III disease, triple-modality therapy was associated with significantly improved survival.
Definitive radiochemotherapy alone was compared to treatment with triple-modality therapy in patients with stage III disease.
A trend towards transoral resection + neck dissection + adjuvant radio- (chemo-) therapy has been observed over the last 20 years.
Transoral surgery techniques have been promoted as gentle, minimally invasive procedures with good late functional outcomes.
TORS may have better disease-free survival and a reduced risk of free flap reconstruction compared to open surgery.

TORS was associated with fewer tumour-positive resection margins, a lower number of recurrences, fewer intraoperative tracheostomies, a shorter hospital stay and a shorter duration of postoperative nasal tube feeding compared to open surgery.
TORS appears to be less time-consuming and associated with less access morbidity compared to conventional surgery.
The ORATOR 1 and ORATOR 2 trials are the only prospective randomized trials that have directly compared TOS with radiochemotherapy.
Primary transoral surgery or the primary non-surgical approach are relevant treatment options for stage I-II oropharyngeal carcinomas.
The UICC stage I and II oropharyngeal carcinomas are p16-positive: T1-T3N2 and p16-neg.: T1-T2N0.
The UICC stage I and II oropharyngeal carcinomas are p16-positive: T1-T3N2 and p16-neg.: T1-T2N0.
The UICC stage I and II oropharyngeal carcinomas are p16-positive: T1-T3N2 and p16-neg.: T1-T2N0.
The total dose of radiotherapy should be de-escalated for primary and adjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy for HPV/p16 positive oropharyngeal carcinoma within clinical trials.
Radiotherapy has undergone significant technical development in the last 20 years.
Intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) is available throughout Germany.
IMRT reduces both acute and late side effects compared to older 3D-conformal radiotherapy.
A randomized study has demonstrated the benefit of Swallowing Sparing IMRT compared to standard IMRT.
Interruptions of radiotherapy lead to repopulation of remaining tumour stem cells.
If there are interruptions to radiotherapy, it is possible to make up for lost time by radiotherapy twice a day at intervals of >6 hours with an unchanged single dose.
Tumour stem cells are also repopulated in the interval between surgical resection and the start of radio- or radiochemotherapy.
If the interval between tumour resection and the start of radiotherapy exceeds 6 weeks, a meta-analysis of the available data shows a significant increase in relapse rates.
The primary non-surgical treatment of patients with HPV/p16-positive and -negative oropharyngeal carcinoma in stage T1 cN0 should be radiotherapy alone.
The primary non-surgical treatment for patients with oropharyngeal carcinoma in stage I cN1 (>1 LK <=3 cm) with HPV/p16+ or stage II should be radiochemotherapy.
Simultaneous chemotherapy should be cisplatin-based in the case of primary radiochemotherapy for HPV/p16-positive and -negative oropharyngeal carcinoma.
Cetuximab should not be used in patients with HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinoma who do not have a contraindication to cisplatin-based chemotherapy.
Cetuximab should not be used in patients with HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinoma due to its proven inferiority in terms of survival.

Radiotherapy should be carried out with 5x2 Gy per week up to a target volume dose of 70 Gy in the area of the affected lymph nodes and the primary tumour or another established regimen with a biologically equivalent total dose.
The UICC stage I and II oropharyngeal carcinomas are p16-positive with T1-T3N2 and p16-negative with T1-T2N0.
The UICC stage I and II oropharyngeal carcinomas are p16-positive with T1-T3N2 and p16-negative with T1-T2N0.
Randomized studies and large registry databases show 5-year survival rates of around 90% in stage I, around 80% in stage II, and around 70% in stage III.
There is a question of whether it is possible to de-escalate the therapy without compromising survival in order to reduce the toxicity of the therapy.

Conventionally fractionated radiotherapy with 5x2 Gy per week up to a total dose of 70 Gy in IMRT technique in combination with 3 x 100 mg/m² cisplatin or 40 mg/m² weekly cisplatin parallel to radiotherapy is the best investigated treatment concept.
A significant advantage was shown in terms of survival and locoregional tumour control for combination chemotherapies applied simultaneously with radiotherapy.
The MACH-NC meta-analysis from 2021 shows that only simultaneous radiochemotherapy leads to an improvement in overall survival and PFS.
The benefit of simultaneous chemotherapy applied in addition to radiotherapy was the same for oropharyngeal carcinoma as for squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, hypopharynx, and oral cavity.
The benefit of simultaneous chemotherapy is the same for HPV/p16- and HPV16+.
The benefit of additional simultaneous chemotherapy in stages I-II is not well documented.
Patients over 70 years of age did not benefit from simultaneous chemotherapy in the MACH-NH meta-analysis.
The NCDB and SEER registry databases documented survival benefits in patients over 70 years of age.
Excluding patients over 70 years of age from simultaneous chemotherapy does not appear justified.
For patients with a contraindication to cisplatin, randomized studies have demonstrated a survival benefit for the simultaneous application of carboplatin and 5-FU.
Randomized studies have also demonstrated a survival benefit for the simultaneous application of mitomycin and 5-FU or weekly docetaxel.
Weekly applications of carboplatin and paclitaxel concurrently with radiotherapy have been investigated in non-randomized phase II trials and retrospective cohort studies.
Radiotherapy should be carried out using the IMRT technique with the best possible protection of the salivary glands, the swallowing tract, and the oral cavity.
The standard fractionation for simultaneous chemotherapy is conventional fractionation with 5x2 Gy per week up to a target volume dose of 70 Gy.
Accelerated radiotherapy with a reduction of the total treatment time to 6 weeks or less has not shown any benefit in combination with simultaneous chemotherapy.
Several randomized trials compared hyperfractionated radiotherapy with simultaneous chemotherapy to hyperfractionated radiotherapy alone.
Adding chemotherapy to hyperfractionated radiotherapy improved survival and locoregional tumour control.
Hyperfractionated radiotherapy was significantly superior to other radiotherapy fractionations in terms of overall survival.
Accelerated radiotherapy regimens only improved locoregional tumour control but did not result in a survival benefit.
Hyperfractionated radiotherapy with simultaneous chemotherapy has not been compared to conventionally fractionated radiotherapy with simultaneous chemotherapy.

A network meta-analysis predicted that hyperfractionated radiotherapy with simultaneous chemotherapy may be more effective than conventionally fractionated radiotherapy with simultaneous chemotherapy.
Post-operative radiotherapy should be started as soon as possible after the wound has healed.
Post-operative radiotherapy should be started within 6 weeks of the operation.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for post-operative radiotherapy.

Patients with HPV/p16 positive oropharyngeal carcinoma in stages I, II who have undergone primary surgical treatment should receive adjuvant radio/radiochemotherapy if R1 or <5mm resection has been performed in healthy tissue.

Patients with HPV/p16 positive oropharyngeal carcinoma in stages I, II who have undergone primary surgical treatment should receive adjuvant radio/radiochemotherapy if solitary lymph node >3cm has been histologically proven.

Patients with HPV/p16 positive oropharyngeal carcinoma in stages I, II who have undergone primary surgical treatment should receive adjuvant radio/radiochemotherapy if more than one tumour-involved lymph node has been histologically proven.

Patients with HPV/p16 positive oropharyngeal carcinoma in stages I, II who have undergone primary surgical treatment should receive adjuvant radio/radiochemotherapy if >= 1 lymph node with ECS has been histologically proven.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for adjuvant radio/radiochemotherapy for patients with HPV/p16 positive oropharyngeal carcinoma.

In patients with HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinoma in stages pT1, pT2 N0 who have undergone primary surgical treatment, adjuvant radio/radiochemotherapy should be given if resection R1 <5mm has been performed in healthy tissue.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for adjuvant radio/radiochemotherapy for patients with HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinoma.
In pT1-pT2 pN0 (M0) HPV/p16-positive and -negative oropharyngeal carcinoma, adjuvant radiotherapy should be dispensed with if the resection >5 mm has been performed in healthy tissue.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for dispensing with adjuvant radiotherapy for pT1-pT2 pN0 (M0) HPV/p16-positive and -negative oropharyngeal carcinoma.

In pT1-pT2 (M0) HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinoma with only one affected lymph node <3cm (without ECS), adjuvant radiotherapy can be dispensed with if all of the following criteria are met.
There is strong consensus on the criteria for dispensing with adjuvant radiotherapy.

Adjuvant irradiation of the region with affected lymph node levels without capsular rupture in HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas should be carried out with 54 - 60 Gy in single doses of 1.8 Gy - 2.0 Gy.
Adjuvant irradiation of affected lymph node levels with capsule breakthrough should be carried out with 66 Gy in single doses of 2.0 - 2.2 Gy.
There is strong consensus on the irradiation dose for affected lymph node levels.
Adjuvant irradiation of unaffected lymph node levels in HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinomas should be carried out with 45- 54 Gy with single doses of 1.5 Gy - 1.8 Gy.
There is strong consensus on the irradiation dose for unaffected lymph node levels.
If adjuvant radiochemotherapy is indicated for HPV/p16-positive or HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinoma, cisplatin-based chemotherapy should be administered simultaneously with radiotherapy.
In patients who cannot receive cisplatin, mitomycin C + 5-FU, carboplatin + 5-FU or docetaxel can be used as simultaneous systemic therapy.
There is strong consensus on this recommendation.
Postoperative radiotherapy has not been investigated in randomized studies.

Cohort studies and prospective registry data showed a superiority of adjuvant radiotherapy in patients with more than one tumour-involved lymph node, extracapsular tumour growth at the lymph nodes (ECE) or with tumours only barely resected in healthy tissue (<5mm).

Adjuvant radiotherapy reduces the locoregional recurrence rate and improves survival in oropharyngeal carcinoma regardless of HPV/p16 status, provided that more than one regional lymph node is affected or the primary tumour was only barely resected in healthy tissue (<5mm).
It can be assumed that the majority of oropharyngeal carcinomas in these studies were HPV/p16-.

The results of the studies consistently showed that patients with evidence of ECE in the affected lymph nodes or R1 resection had a survival benefit from adjuvant radiochemotherapy compared to adjuvant radiotherapy alone.

An analysis based on the NCDB registry compared the results of adjuvant radiochemotherapy with those of adjuvant radiotherapy alone in 1127 patients with HPV/p16+ and 424 patients with HPV/p16- oropharyngeal carcinoma.
The detection of ECE in the lymph nodes of oropharyngeal carcinomas is associated with a significantly higher recurrence rate and poorer survival regardless of HV/p16 status.
Lymph node involvement with ECE in HPV/p16+ oropharyngeal carcinomas is not taken into account in the N classification and staging.
The available data from the registry studies consistently show no benefit of adjuvant radiochemotherapy compared to adjuvant radiotherapy alone for HPV/p16+ oropharyngeal carcinoma.

Data on the relapse pattern after adjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy for HPV/p16+ oropharyngeal carcinoma indicate that the poorer prognosis in patients with ECE to the lymph nodes is almost exclusively due to a higher rate of distant metastasis.

Adjuvant radiotherapy alone may be sufficient for HPV/p16+ oropharyngeal carcinoma, even in cases of lymph node involvement with evidence of ECE, and that additional chemotherapy may not be necessary.

The available registry data show a clear advantage for platinum-containing chemotherapy applied simultaneously with adjuvant radiotherapy for HPV/p16- oropharyngeal carcinomas with evidence of ECE in the lymph nodes.
Less well documented is the influence of positive (<1 mm) or narrow resection margins (<5 mm) on the recurrence rate and survival of oropharyngeal carcinomas depending on HPV/p16 status.
The available data from registry studies show a greater negative impact on the recurrence rate and survival for HPV/p16- oropharyngeal carcinomas than for HPV/p16+ tumours.
Larger resection margins are associated with better treatment results compared to narrow resection margins.
HPV/p16+ oropharyngeal carcinomas have significantly better treatment results in terms of recurrence rate and survival.
A large collective of NCDB patients with HPV/p16+ oropharyngeal carcinoma showed no difference in survival whether adjuvant radiotherapy alone or radiochemotherapy was received.
ECE was detected in the affected lymph nodes of the NCDB patients.
Positive resection margin was present in the NCDB patients.
Cisplatin or cisplatin + 5-FU have shown a significant reduction in the relapse rate or an improvement in survival in randomized studies.
For patients with an intermediate risk of recurrence, 60 Gy was applied in the region of the former primary tumour and the affected lymph nodes in the clinical trials and the registry data.
45-50 Gy with 5x 1.8-2.0 Gy per week were administered electively in the neighbouring unaffected lymph node regions.
There is an international consensus for the selection of the lymph node levels to be electively irradiated.
Lower doses of 50 Gy in conventional fractionation were investigated in smaller phase II studies for HPV/p16+ oropharyngeal carcinomas.
30 Gy with 2x1.5 Gy per day were also investigated in smaller phase II studies for HPV/p16+ oropharyngeal carcinomas.

Primary surgical therapy followed by adjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy is recommended for patients with HPV/p16-positive stage III or HPV/p16-negative stage III-IVb oropharyngeal carcinoma if a good functional outcome and R0 resection are likely to be achievable.

Primary radiochemotherapy is recommended for patients with HPV/p16-positive stage III or HPV/p16-negative stage III-IVb oropharyngeal carcinoma if a good functional outcome and R0 resection are not likely to be achievable.

In patients with HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas who are not treated with surgery, primary radiochemotherapy should be preferred to radiotherapy alone, especially in the age group up to 70 years.
There is an Evidence-based Recommendation for de-escalation of the total dose of radiotherapy for HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinoma within clinical trials.
The Grade of Recommendation for de-escalation of the total dose of radiotherapy is B.
The Level of Evidence for de-escalation of the total dose of radiotherapy is ⊕⊕⊝⊝.
There is a Strong Consensus for de-escalation of the total dose of radiotherapy.
There is an Evidence-based Recommendation for primary conservative therapy for patients with HPV/p16-positive stage III and HPV/p16-negative stage III-IVb oropharyngeal carcinoma.
The Grade of Recommendation for primary conservative therapy is A.
The Level of Evidence for primary conservative therapy is ⊕⊕⊝⊝.
There is a Strong Consensus for primary conservative therapy.
There is an Evidence-based Recommendation for locoregional tumour control and overall survival in patients with HPV/p16-positive stage III and HPV/p16-negative stage III-IVb oropharyngeal carcinoma.
The Grade of Recommendation for locoregional tumour control and overall survival is A.
The Level of Evidence for locoregional tumour control and overall survival is 1a.
There is a Strong Consensus for locoregional tumour control and overall survival.
In HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinoma, simultaneous chemotherapy should be cisplatin-based in the case of primary radiochemotherapy.
The recommendation is evidence-based and has a level of evidence of ⊕⊕⊕⊕.
The recommendation is evidence-based and has a level of evidence of ⊕⊕⊕⊕.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation.
In HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinoma, simultaneous chemotherapy should be cisplatin-based in the case of primary radiochemotherapy.
The recommendation is consensus-based and has a strong consensus.
In patients who cannot receive cisplatin due to impaired renal function, alternative simultaneous systemic therapies can be used.
Alternative simultaneous systemic therapies include carboplatin + 5-FU, mitomycin C + 5-FU, a taxane, or cetuximab (HPV/p16+).
Cetuximab should not be used for HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas that have no contraindication to cisplatin-based chemotherapy.

For primary radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy of HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas in stages I-III, radiotherapy should be carried out with 5x2 Gy per week up to a target volume dose of 70 Gy.
The target volume dose of 70 Gy should be applied to the area of the affected lymph nodes and the primary tumour.
An alternative established regimen with a biologically equivalent total dose can be used.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for radiotherapy.

In primary radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy of HPV/p16-positive and -negative oropharyngeal carcinomas, irradiation of non-affected lymph node levels should be carried out with 45-54 Gy with single doses of 1.5 Gy - 2 Gy.
The elective lymph node levels to be irradiated should be based on the current international consensus.
The elective lymph node levels to be irradiated should be based on the current international consensus.
For HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas, the dose should be between 50 Gy and 60 Gy with individual doses of 1.5 to 2.0 Gy, depending on the risk.
The dose for HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas should be applied to the lymph node levels to be electively irradiated.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for the dose for HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas.
Primary radio- or radiochemotherapy of HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas in stages III or III-IVb should be carried out using the IMRT technique.
The IMRT technique should be used with the best possible protection of the salivary glands, the unaffected swallowing tract and the oral cavity.
The recommended doses in the target volumes should not be fallen below when using the IMRT technique.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for the use of the IMRT technique.
Post-operative radiotherapy should be started as soon as possible after the wound has healed and within 6 weeks of the operation.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for post-operative radiotherapy.

Patients with HPV/p16-positive stage III and HPV/p16-negative stage III-IVb oropharyngeal carcinoma who have undergone primary surgical treatment should receive adjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for adjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy.

Adjuvant radiochemotherapy should be given after primary surgical treatment of HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas in stage III or III-IVb if the resection <5mm has been performed in healthy tissue or if extracapsular tumour growth in one or more lymph nodes has been histologically proven.
There is strong consensus on the recommendation for adjuvant radiochemotherapy.
Adjuvant irradiation of unaffected lymph node levels in HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas should be carried out with 45-54 Gy with single doses of 1.5 Gy - 1.8 Gy.
There is a strong consensus on the recommendation for adjuvant irradiation of unaffected lymph node levels.
If adjuvant radiochemotherapy is indicated for HPV/p16-positive or HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinoma, cisplatin-based chemotherapy should be administered simultaneously with radiotherapy.
In patients who cannot receive cisplatin, mitomycin C + 5-FU, carboplatin + 5-FU or docetaxel can be used as simultaneous systemic therapy.
There is a strong consensus on the recommendation for adjuvant radiochemotherapy.
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy prior to planned definitive radio- or radiochemotherapy should not be carried out for HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas.
This recommendation is based on evidence with a level of evidence of 1++ and a grade of recommendation of A.
There is strong consensus on this recommendation.
There is strong consensus on this recommendation.

Neoadjuvant or adjuvant systemic therapy should only be used for primary surgical therapy or definitive radio- or radiochemotherapy for HPV/p16-positive and HPV/p16-negative oropharyngeal carcinomas within clinical trials.
This recommendation is based on consensus and has an evidence category of EC.
Induction concepts and adjuvant, purely drug-based therapy concepts are not generally recommended for the primary treatment of oropharyngeal carcinoma.
Oropharyngeal carcinomas with distant metastases are classified as UICC stages IV p16-positive:M1 and stage IV-C p16-neg.

In the case of a tumour that has already metastasized at a distance at the time of initial diagnosis, the limited curative treatment options and the very limited prognosis must be strictly weighed in the interdisciplinary tumour board.
The treatment options for oropharyngeal carcinomas with distant metastases are subsumed under the generic term of palliative medical treatment.
The principles in these tumour standards apply equally to squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity, oropharynx (p16-pos. and -neg.), hypopharynx and larynx.

A further important observation on the field carcinogenization of hypopharyngeal carcinomas was observed after very good survival rates of T4b hypopharyngeal carcinomas with infiltration of the upper oesophagus after radical laryngohypopharyngoesophagectomy.

Radical laryngohypopharyngoesophagectomy involves resection of the hypopharynx with the entire oesophagus with consecutive gastric pull-up as oesophageal replacement and adjuvant radiotherapy with 60 Gy in conventional fractionation.
The analysis revealed a group of 45 aberrantly expressed proteins that were only detectable in the cancer patients.
The 5-year survival rates of these patients showed that the signature proved to be predictive of the presence of field cancerization in the oesophagus.
All patients with hypopharyngeal carcinoma and the named signature in the oesophagus had died.
80% of patients without this signature in the oesophagus survived.
Squamous cell carcinomas of the hypopharynx behave in a similar aggressive manner to those of the oesophagus.
Locoregional metastases occur very early in hypopharyngeal carcinoma and the stage distribution at initial diagnosis tends to be predominantly advanced compared to other head and neck entities.
>80% of hypopharyngeal carcinomas are diagnosed at stages III, IV at initial diagnosis.
The comparatively poor prognosis decreases further with increasing patient age.

In a registry study (SEER 1780 patients), the following were shown to have an unfavourable prognosis: older patients with a higher T category, advanced N category, hypopharyngeal posterior wall involvement, multiple distant metastases and no reasonably possible surgical treatment with the aim of R0 resection (inoperability) of the primary tumour.
A subgroup of 21% of patients with HPV/p16-positive hypopharyngeal carcinomas in a registry study (NCDB, 2004 - 2016; 9314 patients) showed significantly better therapy-independent overall survival.
Primary surgical treatment +/- adjuvant radio- or radiochemotherapy and primary radio- or radiochemotherapy have been established as primary treatments for localized hypopharyngeal carcinomas.

There is no evidence that transoral treatment procedures (TLM, TORS) are inferior to open transcervical surgical procedures for T1 and T2 hypopharyngeal carcinoma in terms of tumour recurrence rate and survival.
Hypopharyngeal carcinomas in stages cT1-cT2 cN0 cM0 should be treated either with primary resection +/- adjuvant radio- or radiochemotherapy or with primary radio- or radiochemotherapy.
Organ-preserving surgery is only rarely considered for carcinomas of the hypopharynx due to the advanced stage of the tumour at the time of diagnosis.
Patients with hypopharyngeal carcinomas are often in an unfavourable general clinical condition due to extensive comorbidities.
Hypopharyngeal carcinoma has the least favourable prognosis of all squamous cell carcinomas of the head and neck in Europe.
A careful preoperative risk assessment is necessary before therapeutic considerations, especially primary surgical measures, and intensive postoperative monitoring is often planned.
Advances in open laryngeal surgery and TLM have enabled oncologically safe R0 tumour resections with acceptable functional restrictions in some patients with hypopharyngeal carcinomas.
One of the basic principles of oncological surgery is that a complete, histologically verifiable R0 resection (>5mm) must be guaranteed.
If a complete tumour resection is not reliably possible as part of an intended surgical procedure, alternative treatment options must be chosen as a matter of priority.

In the case of hypopharyngeal carcinomas, whether a complete tumour resection will be possible can only be assessed by reviewing the endoscopic findings and meaningful imaging and preoperative swallowing diagnostics by FEES.
The treatment of hypopharyngeal carcinoma worldwide includes TORS.
Patients with smaller tumours of the medial wall of the piriform sinus and the postcricoid region are particularly suitable for TLM.
Patients with smaller and superficially growing tumours of the lateral wall of the piriform sinus and the posterior wall of the hypopharynx are particularly suitable for TLM.
TLM is not feasible for tumours in the area of the apex of the piriform sinus and the oesophageal orifice.
In a TLM clinic, surgical treatment was only possible in 136 patients out of 228 consecutive patients with hypopharyngeal carcinomas.
Only around 20% of all patients with hypopharyngeal carcinoma can undergo larynx-preserving surgery.
If the tumour reaches the resection margins, a subsequent resection should be attempted in order to achieve an R0 result.
The indications for organ-preserving TLM in the hypopharynx range from T1 to T4a tumours with good results.
Steiner et al. published local control rates over five years of 84% pT1; 70% pT2; 75% pT3; 57% pT4a.
Steiner et al. published recurrence-free 5-year survival of 73% for stages I and II, 59% for stage III, 47% for stage IVa.
Eckel et al. showed an uncorrected survival of 59.3% and a local control rate of 73.3% in large collectives after 5 years.
Eckel et al. showed that 76.5% of all patients had a functioning larynx after 5 years.
Rudert et al. showed an uncorrected survival of 48% and a disease-specific survival of 58%.
Rudert et al. showed a disease-specific survival of 71% in stages I and II.
In carefully selected patients with early hypopharyngeal carcinoma, transoral laser surgery leads to very good oncological and functional results.
There is only one comparative study worldwide to date on TORS versus open surgery, in which only hypopharyngeal carcinomas were treated.
Primary non-surgical therapy for patients with hypopharyngeal carcinomas in stages I-II (UICC 8th edition) should receive radiotherapy alone.
Radiochemotherapy may be offered for larger T2 tumours.
Cisplatin-based chemotherapy should be administered simultaneously with radiotherapy for stage II hypopharyngeal carcinoma.

For primary radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy of hypopharyngeal carcinoma in stages I-II (UICC 8th edition), radiotherapy should be carried out with 5 x 2 Gy per week up to a target volume dose of 70 Gy in the area of the affected lymph nodes and the primary tumour.
Irradiation of unaffected lymph node levels should be carried out with 45 - 54 Gy with individual doses of 1.5 Gy - 1.8 Gy.
The elective lymph node levels to be irradiated should be based on the current international consensus.
The primary radio- or radiochemotherapy of hypopharyngeal carcinomas in stages I and II should be carried out using the IMRT technique.
The IMRT technique should provide the best possible protection of the salivary glands, the unaffected parts of the swallowing tract and the oral cavity.
The recommended doses in the target volumes should not be fallen below.
Organ preservation by means of primary radiochemotherapy or induction chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy should be discussed on an interdisciplinary basis for larger T2 tumours.
The same principles apply to the dosage and fractionation of radiotherapy as for HPV/p16-positive oropharyngeal carcinomas.
Radiotherapy was carried out in most studies on radio- or radiochemotherapy with 5 x 2 Gy per week up to target volume doses of 70 Gy in the area of the primary tumour and the affected lymph nodes.
Slightly accelerated and also hyperfractionated radiation regimens with biologically equivalent doses give approximately equivalent results.

No advantage in terms of relapse-free survival or overall survival with simultaneous radiochemotherapy compared to radiochemotherapy alone has been established for squamous cell carcinoma of the pharynx, larynx and oral cavity in stages I+II.

Patients with stage I+II hypopharyngeal carcinoma who have undergone primary surgical treatment should receive adjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy if resection R1 or <5mm has been performed in healthy tissue.
Adjuvant radiotherapy can also be offered for G3, L1, V1 or Pn1.
The recommendation to receive adjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy is based on strong consensus.
If adjuvant radiotherapy is indicated for hypopharyngeal carcinoma in stages I+II, radiotherapy should be given with 60 - 66 Gy in the area of the narrow resection margins.
Radiotherapy should be given with 45 - 54 Gy with single doses of 1.5 Gy - 1.8 Gy in the area of unaffected lymph node levels.
The recommendation for the dosage of radiotherapy is based on strong consensus.
